name: Ruddock, Philip, MP
text:
—by leave—In 1996, the coalition went to the Australian people with a very strong commitment to Australia's migration program. On coming to government we moved quickly to ensure that Australia's migration policy and program best suited Australia's national interest and our international responsibilities. This included restoring the integrity of the migration program and community support for it. We have been successful, and remain strongly committed to a managed migration program that benefits all Australians both now and in the future.
As members would know, Australia has a long tradition of migration. Indeed, Australia has been built on settlement from other countries. In many ways this has determined the very nature of contemporary Australian society. The six million migrants who have come to Australia since World War II represent 150 different nationalities and 200 different language groups, and practise more than 70 religions. Australia is one of only a few countries in the world that have operated a planned immigration program for over 50 years. Australia has an ongoing humanitarian program which provides for 12,000 new places a year. 
This financial year, the Australian migration program will be the largest and most highly skilled in over a decade, with a planning level set in the range of 100,000 to 110,000 places. We plan to maintain the program at this level over the next four financial years. The program will continue to be a central contributor to the economic and social development of Australia while helping to ensure that skill shortages do not hold back the Australian economy. 
Our immigration policies are underpinned by the following essential core values.
Firstly, migrant selection is strictly non-discriminatory as far as matters such as race, religion, colour or ethnicity are concerned.
Secondly, Australians can be reunited in Australia with their non-Australian partners or dependent children, and in time those persons can become Australian citizens.
Thirdly, the overall immigration intake is demonstrably in the national economic interest. If this were not the case, Australia's standard of living would deteriorate, community support for immigration would rapidly diminish, and Australia's capacity to provide a humanitarian program would be reduced.
Fourthly, Australia contributes its fair share to the resettlement of those most in need—the principle of international burden sharing. In resettling refugees, the government devotes very considerable resources to ensuring that these people have the support they need to fully participate as members of the Australian community.
And last, but by no means least, the government must have the capacity to manage the movement of people across Australia's borders in an orderly and efficient manner.
Without this critical capacity, a managed immigration policy rapidly becomes meaningless.
In recent years we have experienced changing situations challenging Australia's border integrity.
The unauthorised arrivals challenge
In August 2001 Australia was confronted with an unprecedented situation. During the first three weeks of August, some 1,212 unauthorised arrivals entered by boats. There were credible intelligence reports suggesting another 5,000 persons were signed up to travel this way. Unless something was done, there was the potential that more than 8,000 unauthorised arrivals would enter Australia in 2001-02, possibly growing to some 12,000 in 2002-03. This was the size of the total Humanitarian Resettlement Program expected for that year.
This would have eliminated Australia's capacity to help the most needy: those who are generally unseen and unheard—the often forgotten refugees who cannot use people smugglers.
People smugglers organising these unauthorised boats were well aware that if they could get their `customers' to Australia, be it mainland Australia or its external territories, then under Australian law they would get access to a very comprehensive and generous refugee determination system with:
·	an expansive interpretation of the Refugees Convention by our courts;
·	access to medical benefits and income support; and
·	the support of various NGOs, churches and others who are well meaning in the pursuit of offering assistance.
Importantly also, the smugglers could offer the potential for those found to be refugees to obtain lawful residence in Australia. Something had to be done to prevent this growing trend of people smugglers being able to sell their services with such an attractive package of inducements and thus undermine the international system of protection.
The Tampa incident clearly demonstrated the strength of the threat to the integrity of Australia's borders. Notwithstanding that the MV Tampa was on a journey headed towards Indonesia and had authority from the Indonesian government to proceed to Merak to disembark the persons it had rescued at sea, the rescuees compelled the captain, under duress, to turn the Tampa around and head to the Australian territory of Christmas Island.
The flagrant and threatening demands of these persons to enter Australia without authority were totally unacceptable to the Australian government. We had to take firm action to maintain our ability to manage the movement of people across our borders in an orderly and efficient way.
Our response
Legislative measures
As a result of these challenges, the government introduced a range of legislative measures that were passed by the parliament in September 2001.
Members will recall that these measures included:
·	preventing visa applications from unauthorised arrivals at Christmas Island, the Cocos-Keeling Islands and Ashmore and Cartier Islands while they were in those territories of Australia;
·	power to move these persons to declared countries, where any asylum claims could be assessed;
·	power to detain vessels and persons seeking to enter Australia without authority; 
·	a new offshore humanitarian visa system to encourage persons who had, or could seek effective protection in a country of first asylum to remain in that country; and
·	minimum sentences for people smugglers.
These changes are fully consistent with Australia's international obligations.
The parliament also passed measures that the government had proposed earlier to address the high number of visa applicants who were using Australia's judicial review processes to delay their removal from Australia.
Central to these measures is the introduction of a privative clause, which widens the lawfulness of visa decisions, thereby reducing the grounds upon which the courts can set aside a visa decision as being unlawful. These limited grounds are intended to enable courts to quickly determine judicial review applications, thereby reducing delays in removal of non-citizens and leading to lower costs to the Australian taxpayer.
Historically, the time taken to resolve migration related matters in the Federal Court have been lengthy, with many applicants using the court processes to delay their removal from Australia. The introduction of the privative clause has contributed to markedly reducing these delays. For example, in the 2001-02 financial year the average time to resolve a non-privative clause matter before the Federal Court and the Federal Magistrates Court was almost 190 days. For the same year privative clause matters were resolved in approximately 95 days. That is a very significant change of more than 50 per cent.
Other actions
These legislative measures are one element of the measures that the government has taken. Briefly, other initiatives include:
·	increased funding to international programs which go to directly assisting refugees and which can be accessed by a range of international organisations;
·	providing assistance to UNHCR to process asylum claims while persons are in other countries, such as Indonesia—to discourage persons from embarking on the extremely hazardous voyage to Australia;
·	encouraging greater global and regional cooperation in combating people smuggling activities, such as co-hosting with Indonesia a conference in Bali in February 2002, with a further conference, as outlined by the foreign minister today, scheduled for April 2003;
·	enhanced visa integrity measures, which have brought about a decline in the number of protection visa applications by persons having entered Australia lawfully; and
·	continuing onshore compliance activity, which has led to greater location of overstayers and persons breaching visa conditions, which I have outlined in the House before. We have seen a 100 per cent increase in the numbers of locations of overstayers since we came to office.
The operation of processing centres in Nauru and Papua New Guinea is also part of our comprehensive strategy. Persons who have been taken to these centres have access to appropriate arrangements for refugee determination and, where appropriate, for refugee protection.
The centres are run by the International Organisation for Migration IOM, which is known internationally for its care of migrants and asylum seekers. Nearly all the asylum seekers live in airconditioned accommodation, food is culturally appropriate and there is a good range of amenities for the residents. 
Refugee assessments have been undertaken, in some cases by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, and by experienced Australian officials who have applied processes and standards similar to those of the UNHCR.
The decisions by countries including Nauru, Papua New Guinea and New Zealand to cooperate with Australia in processing unauthorised boat arrivals and resettling of some of those in need of protection reinforce the commitment of countries in the Asia-Pacific region to working together to combat people-smuggling and illegal migration.
All our actions have been fully consistent with Australia's international obligations.
Immigration detention
Detention of all unlawful non-citizens, including unauthorised arrivals, remains a key element of effective immigration control.
It is essential for safeguarding the Australian community while identity, security and health checks are undertaken and while a person's claims to remain in Australia are assessed. This has been recognised by successive governments since its introduction in 1992. An important part of effective border control is the ability to remove persons with no right to remain in Australia—immigration detention ensures those persons are available for removal.
The large influx of unauthorised boat arrivals presented challenges in the provision of a safe and secure detention environment. Further challenges were presented by a very demanding detainee population who had false expectations, often arising from misinformation provided by people smugglers, which sometimes led to rioting and attempts to enter the Australian community.
Sheer numbers of unauthorised arrivals and misbehaviour of course should not be the reasons for the removal of immigration detention—to do so would demonstrate to people smugglers that they can control our immigration policies and programs.
There has been a large decrease over the last year in the overall numbers of people in immigration detention. In November 2001 there were some 3,400 people detained in immigration detention facilities in Australia, of whom 748 were children. This represented a reduction from the historically high number of 3,721 people who were in detention in August of that year.
As at 21 November 2002 there were only 1,282 people in detention, of whom fewer than 600 were unauthorised boat arrivals—I might even say a little over 500. Of these, there are 139 children under the age of 18. That is, less than 20 per cent of the number detained 12 months ago. Of these 139, seven are residing at the Woomera Residential Housing Project. Seventeen are unaccompanied minors, of whom 12 are in foster care or alternative detention arrangements in the community. Only five remain in detention centres. Most of those five have been detained as a result of recent compliance action by the department.
One hundred of the children in detention are school aged. Forty-nine currently attend either government or non-government schools in the community. This does not include the five primary school-aged children at Woomera who recently began attending a non-government school at Roxby Downs two days a week.
The main impediments to children attending schools in the community are the views of state education authorities and local communities. A constructive role the Labor opposition might play would be to talk to some of their colleagues in state government—after all, they are in government in eight locations—and seek their cooperation in relation to achieving those outcomes.
This decline in young people and others held in detention is a result of the halting of unauthorised boat arrivals since December 2001, the release from detention of those found to be owed protection and the removal from Australia of those found not to be owed protection.
The government has worked hard to reduce the time taken to reach decisions on applications for protection visas and thus the time that unauthorised arrivals spend in detention. Not only have processing times by my department been reduced considerably but, as at 21 November 2002, there were only 13 detainees awaiting a primary decision by my department, only four of whom were unauthorised boat arrivals. The delay in making primary decisions in relation to those 13 detainees primarily relates to protracted identification, security and character issues. 
Within the mandatory detention framework and consistent with the Migration Act, the government is continuing to take innovative approaches to alternative places of detention that meet the objectives of having people available for processing and, if required, removal.
It was to this end that I commissioned the residential housing trial at Woomera last year. The trial, although very costly, has been a success, and I have agreed to expand the eligibility criteria for children and women who wish to participate in the residential housing trial so that those cases that have proceeded beyond primary and merits review stage may also be considered. I have also given approval for compelling cases or those with special needs to be considered on a case-by-case basis for release into other alternative places of detention. There are numbers of people who are in that circumstance now and have been over a period of time.
I have also raised with the South Australian government options for the development of a residential housing project in either Port Augusta or Whyalla. Community consultations will take place if agreement in principle can be achieved between Premier Rann and people like Mayor Baluch of Port Augusta.
Within the framework of mandatory detention, some time ago I requested my department to develop further flexible detention arrangements to cater for detainees with special needs, such as women and children. These arrangements build on the success of the Woomera residential housing trial for those families with children. These detention arrangements enable individual needs to be addressed while maintaining the effective controls that immigration detention provides. Guidelines for these arrangements have been issued, and I am going to table them today for the information of members.
Those flexible detention arrangements build on processes which were put in place earlier this year when most unaccompanied minors at the Woomera Immigration Reception and Processing Centre were removed to alternative places of detention, including foster care, under special arrangements with the South Australian child welfare agency.
Formal guidelines for unaccompanied minors have now been developed at my request, which should ensure that, except in exceptional circumstances, all unaccompanied minors in detention will be moved quickly to an alternative place of detention. I am also tabling a copy of the guidelines that are applied for determining those matters for the information of members.
As at 22 November 2002, there were only two children—both 17—in a detention centre in Australia of whom I am the guardian. In addition, at this date, there are another three children in detention centres whom my department would normally treat for care and monitoring purposes as unaccompanied minors. One of these children is in the care of other family members—that is, other than their parents—and the other two are not covered by the relevant enactment due to their immigration status on arrival in Australia.
In examining alternative detention arrangements, the government has to give due weight to issues of financial, economic and social cost and the consequences in any assessment of alternative arrangements. These arrangements need to be assessed carefully on a case-by-case basis, taking into account the special needs of the individuals concerned and the ability of the government to responsibly respond.
The results: a year later (October 02)
Success of Pacific solution
I would like to inform the House of the results a year later. Firstly, because it has often been brought into question, I will address the issue of the success of the Pacific solution. It has never been claimed that the Pacific solution was the only approach that should be taken; our approach has always been to adopt a range of initiatives, all of which we think contribute to deterring unauthorised boat arrivals. Since September last year, some 1,515 unauthorised arrivals have been taken to Nauru and Manus in Papua New Guinea for processing of their asylum claims. To date, 1,497 cases have been determined—736 have been determined to be refugees and 761 not to be refugees.  
Of those determined to be refugees, to date some 310 people with family links to Australia have been granted temporary protection in Australia, 202 have been resettled in New Zealand and 14 in Sweden. There have been ongoing discussions with a range of other countries, including Canada and certain Scandinavian countries, which have agreed in principle to assist in the resettlement of the remaining refugees.
The vast majority—619—of the 761 rejected asylum seekers were Afghans. Others included 105 Iraqis and 37 from other nationalities. On 16 May, I signed an agreement with the Afghan administration on the voluntary return of Afghans who have not engaged Australia's protection obligations. We were one of the first governments to do that. A number of other governments have since that time put in place such agreements. That agreement, which provided for voluntary return of Afghans who had not engaged our obligations, has led to some 470 people taking advantage of our reintegration assistance package. As at 20 November 2002, 155 Afghans have returned to Afghanistan under those arrangements, and we anticipate a further 110 to 120 Afghans leaving Nauru during this month. The pace in relation to being able to facilitate those returns is not a matter of our doing. Rather, it is the capacity of the Afghan Embassy in Australia to issue appropriate documents after initiating their own inquiries, which have often involved them having to visit Nauru and seek information from Afghanistan.
To further assist in this voluntary repatriation process, the Australian government has provided a range of assistance to the Afghan government, including the provision of some $200,000 to facilitate vocational training of returnees, and considerable resources have been devoted to the refurbishment of a reception centre in Kabul, the Jangalak Centre, to assist returnees in their reintegration process. I have accepted an invitation from the foreign affairs minister of Afghanistan's interim administration to participate in the opening of the centre, which will hopefully be in the new year.
This reintegration program for Afghans is being seen as a model for other countries and regions of the world.
The results of our regional cooperation agreement with Indonesia, which funds the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees and the International Organisation for Migration to process asylum seekers in Indonesia, has also resulted in a reduction in the number of asylum seekers that would have reached Australia's shores.
From 1999 to 31 October 2002, 3,830 people had been interdicted en route to Australia and placed under the care of the International Organisation for Migration under the informal regional cooperative arrangements that Indonesia, the International Organisation for Migration and the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees have in place.
Of those, 910 had been recognised through processing undertaken by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees as refugees in need of protection and who are available for resettlement.
Some 389 have been resettled from Indonesia at this point in time. Ten countries have been involved in that resettlement, with 89.4 per cent going to countries other than Australia.
In addition, the International Organisation for Migration has facilitated 512 voluntary returns to countries of origin, mainly Afghanistan and Pakistan.
Under similar arrangements that were put in place with Cambodia, 248 people, including seven crew of the vessel that was interdicted en route to Australia, were placed under the care of the International Organisation for Migration. Of those, 14 had been recognised by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees as in need of resettlement, and the International Organisation for Migration has facilitated the return of 234 voluntary returnees to countries of origin. In that case most of them were from Pakistan. 
We have had just over 15 months since any boat organised by people smugglers and carrying groups of unvisaed persons has arrived in Australia. We have also had about 12 months since any substantial attempt to enter Australian waters has been made. One wonders why in those very changed circumstances, particularly when processing is not occurring onshore, there is so much preoccupation with detention.
By any measure, this comprehensive strategy has been successful. There are many countries around the world that would like to be in the position we are in, having achieved that outcome.
However—and in my view, most importantly—it has stopped people risking their lives in dangerous journeys organised by people smugglers. I lament very much that many people have lost their lives tragically, putting themselves in the hands of people smugglers. Perhaps there were many whom we have never known were travelling and are perhaps lost. That was certainly the case I think 2½ or three years ago when there were suggestions that some vessels that were destined for Australia left and were not seen again.
As a consequence, visa processing costs have been significantly contained. People have suggested that, because we devoted some additional resources to having people processed offshore in Nauru and Manus, that was not a good investment. Let me make the point: the protection visa processing on the Australian mainland costs in the order of $125 million, as against $190 million provided in the 2001 budget. We expect a saving of some $65 million as a result of containing the movement to Australia. A further saving of $85 million is likely for onshore processing of unauthorised boat arrivals. That has been announced in the context of the 2002-03 budget.
Processing at processing centres in Papua New Guinea and Nauru was $112 million, as against the provision of $159 million in the budget for 2001-02. Given that there have been no new unauthorised boat arrivals for over 12 months, processing costs are expected to reduce considerably in the year 2002-03 and to continue to reduce in subsequent years.
It can be seen that the offshore processing regime has been very beneficial economically and in budget terms. It has reduced the incentive of people smugglers being able to assure their potential clients that they would be able to get to Australia's mainland processing where they would receive a more generous result, as well as access to income support services. It has enabled us to have an offshore humanitarian program of over 12,000 places in the year 2002-03—the highest for some years.
Conclusion
The initiatives taken by the government since August last year have resulted in the government enhancing its ability to manage an orderly immigration program to the national benefit.
These initiatives contribute to Australia continuing to have economic and social capacity to put into practice the nation's commitment to assist those at greatest risk.
We have expended considerable effort and resources in ensuring that protection is provided to those who need it, the work of people smugglers is defeated, and those not in need of protection returned to their home country. We have been prepared to do this in the face of very considerable criticism.
Why have we been prepared to do that? Firstly, because we believe that this approach `saves lives'. It removes the incentive for people to leave places of protection and to risk their lives in dangerous journeys with people smugglers. Secondly, it provides us with the capacity and resources to assist those refugees we cannot see and whose voices are not heard—refugees who have no capacity to move, who cannot afford a people smuggler and whose only prospect of a durable solution, given the danger that they might well be in, is resettlement.
I was recently in Tanzania. I visited the UNHCR's refugee camps at Lukole and was shown the clear potential for the successful repatriation of many people to Burundi. But I also came away with the very clear picture of a limited number of refugees within the total caseload who will never be able to return to or integrate with the community in Burundi or stay where they are. These are people for whom the UNHCR has said resettlement is the only option available. I have come face to face, in other camps and places, with sizeable numbers of refugees in similar circumstances. 
International efforts to assist refugees require practical strategies—strategies which marshal and focus all the available resources of nations for the benefit of those most in need. The government has adopted policy positions that allow Australia both to meet our protection obligations towards refugees who require protection and to continue to resettle some of those who do not have the choice of arriving here without authority. Annually, we have made 12,000 places available to assist those most at risk. This number has been set after taking into account our capacity and resources to provide humanitarian protection. In recent years, the pressure of large numbers of unauthorised arrivals has reduced that capacity to resettle from offshore the full 12,000 places. We needed to take the action that we have in order to ensure that we can continue to assist those most at risk.
I do not suggest that this has been an easy choice to make. I understand the compassion that draws focus and attention to asylum seekers whom we see and hear, those who arrive on our shores. But I reiterate that Australians, as compassionate people, have to be prepared to make hard choices. We may feel sorry for all people in less fortunate circumstances, but we cannot help all of those who seek our help. We have to make choices and, to retain community support for a resettlement program, we have to be able to effectively manage our borders to ensure that those most in need of assistance are able to obtain it. I present copies of the migration series instruction Nos 370 and 371 and a copy of the following ministerial statement:
Managing Migration—Ministerial Statement, 3 December 2002.
Mr WILLIAMS (Tangney—Attorney-General) (4.18 p.m.)—I move:
That the House take note of the paper.
Mr WILLIAMS (Tangney—Attorney-General) (4.18 p.m.)—by leave—I move:
That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent Ms Gillard speaking for a period not exceeding 35 minutes.
Question agreed to.

name: Gillard, Julia, MP
text:
—Due to a Steve Bracks induced cold as a result of doing how-to-votes on the weekend, I doubt whether I am capable of speaking for 35 minutes, but I am grateful for the opportunity to respond. Today's `ministerial statement' should really have been styled a `ministerial response'. Why is the statement being released today? I do not think there is any doubt that it is being released today because it is today that Labor's new policy `Protecting Australia and protecting the Australian way' went to our Labor Party caucus for consideration. That is why we are here listening to a ministerial statement today.
In terms of the content, why is this statement being released at all? I do not think there is any mystery about that either. This statement is being released as a result of the amendment that Labor moved to the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002. For the information of honourable members, I will remind them of that amendment. That amendment was to introduce into the Migration Act a new section 197D, which would have compelled the government to release any unaccompanied child from high-security detention. Then there was the introduction into the Migration Act by that amendment of a new section 197E, which was aimed at compelling the government to have children with family members live in detention accommodation akin to the Woomera alternate detention trial. Those amendments were moved in August.
When those amendments were moved, the response from the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs—and, indeed, from the Prime Minister—was to suggest that the amendments were ridiculous, would cause major problems and would cause endless litigation and the like. I note, for example, that the minister for immigration claimed that the definition of `unaccompanied detained child' used by Labor in those amendments would lead to litigation—indeed, endless litigation. In fact, we now find with this statement today that the government is defining `unaccompanied detained children' by reference to the same act that Labor used in its definition—that is, by reference to the Immigration (Guardianship of Children) Act 1946. So an idea from Labor about how to define `detained children', viewed as ridiculous by the government at the time, is now incorporated. Then we had no less than the Prime Minister hitting the radios to tell the Australian people: 
We have tried the idea of having them out in the community with their mothers and the reaction has been that they don't want to be separated from their fathers. And if you put the whole family out the danger is they just melt into the community ...
...			...				...
... our view remains that if you go beyond having your mother and children then you do run the risk that people abscond ...
So we had a reaction from the government to suggest that moving family groups, extending the Woomera alternate detention trial, would in some way breach security.
What has changed between August, when Labor moved this amendment and when the government response was that it should not even be considered, and today, when we have a ministerial statement which has picked up large parts of Labor's proposal? I can tell you quite simply what has changed. A number of Liberal moderates indicated to refugee advocacy groups, the minister for immigration and, if the press is to be believed, the Prime Minister that, if the government took no steps to remedy the circumstances of children in detention, they would seriously consider crossing the floor and voting for Labor's amendment. The only reason we are here today is that, in response to those threats from some Liberal moderates, the government thought it had better act before the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002 and Labor's amendment come on for full debate next week.
I want to say to Liberal moderates who were actually concerned about these issues that there is good cause to be concerned—very good cause to be concerned. Yesterday in question time I raised with the minister the finding of the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission in relation to a complaint brought by Mr Mohammed Badraie on behalf of his young son Shayan. I think the case is familiar to most of us, from the Four Corners episode which dealt with the disturbing condition this child was in as a result of his experiences in detention. Yesterday Minister Ruddock did not know anything about this report. I suspect that by today he does. 
When people read this report—and it is a lengthy one—they will see that it is a disturbing litany of what goes wrong when children are held in high-security detention. I do not intend to take the House through it in detail today, but let me say this. The recommendations find, on the basis that this child's human rights were breached, that a figure of $70,000 in compensation needs to be paid and that apologies need to be extended to this child and his family in writing by the minister on behalf of the minister's department. When you read this report and come to the recommendations, you have no option but to conclude that the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission has got it right. Indeed, Labor has had it right from Australia Day, when it called for children to be brought out from behind the razor wire. I seek leave to table that report.
Leave not granted.
—The statement made today was lengthy. As distributed, it was 14 pages; as people are aware, it took some time to read. Out of the 14 pages, there are actually three that deal with new initiatives—three in 14 pages. The rest is a work of self-congratulation about what has been done in the past. The three paragraphs that actually deal with potential new policy read as follows:
To this end I commissioned the Residential Housing Trial at Woomera last year. The trial, though costly, has been a success. I have agreed to expand the eligibility criteria ...
It goes on for a sentence or two to talk about the expansion of the eligibility criteria. That is paragraph No. 1 out of a 14-page statement that includes something new. Paragraph No. 2 out of a 14-page statement that includes something new states:
 I have also raised with the South Australian Government options for the development of a Residential Housing Project in Port Augusta or Whyalla. Community consultations will take place if agreement in principle is achieved with Premier Rann and Mayor Baluch. 
That is not so much an announcement of new policy as a suggestion that, if they manage to progress something with the state government to in principle agreement, they will further consult with the community. 
Out of three action paragraphs in this 14-page statement, one is about expanding eligibility for a trial and one is about engaging in a process which might ultimately lead to community consultations about something that they might do. The other action paragraph in this 14-page statement indicates that the minister will issue guidelines—and he has issued them today—about getting unaccompanied minors out of detention. 
What does this all amount to? It is 14 pages, a 35-minute contribution to the House. All it amounts to is the following. The government is issuing a migration series instruction so that unaccompanied minors will not be in high-security detention. Let us hold that up against the test of Labor's amendment—the amendment that actually provoked this statement today—and see whether it passes the test. In terms of it passing the test, let me say the following. Firstly, the problem with the migration series instruction is, of course, that it does not give you the security or certainty of a law. Labor was trying to change the Migration Act to make it standing long-term policy that unaccompanied children could not be held in high-security detention. I would say to Liberal moderates who were attracted to voting for Labor's amendment that they would really need to think through whether something that has the status of a migration series instruction is good enough to deal with such a major issue.
Let me also say that, when viewed against the policy proposals Labor has in this area, the proposal being advanced by the minister is nowhere near good enough. The policy proposals that were presented to Labor caucus today and have been endorsed by Labor's shadow cabinet actually deal with two very big things that this policy statement— this ministerial statement—does not deal with at all. One is that this ministerial statement does not deal with most children who are in detention. Most children who are in detention are actually detained on Nauru or in Papua New Guinea in accordance with the so-called Pacific solution. Minister Ruddock went through the number of children in Australian detention, but he forgot to tell us about the 38 on Manus Island and the 149 in Nauru. Nothing contained in this statement affects the circumstances of those children at all. Viewed against the backdrop of Labor's policy as being discussed by our caucus at the moment, this is an insufficient response. Any child—whether here in Australia or whether subject to the Pacific solution— should have their rights and their circumstances considered; this ministerial statement simply does not do so.
This ministerial statement leaves untouched another policy issue that Labor feels is very important, and that is the question of the guardianship of unaccompanied children. Formally, the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural and Indigenous Affairs is the guardian of unaccompanied children. There clearly is a conflict of interest or, at the very least, a perception of a conflict of interest, and we believe that ought to be addressed by moving the guardianship to an appropriate other entity. Under Labor's suggestion, that entity would be the children's commissioner which Labor policy would introduce to deal with children's issues broadly from the perspective of the federal government. 
Now let us move to that part of the statement which deals with accompanied children—that is, children who are here in family groups. Is this statement sufficient? Once again, let me remind you that most children in detention will not be touched by this statement, because most children in detention are detained on Manus Island and Nauru. The proposal here is that only women and children—no male family members and no older male children—are allowed to move to the alternate detention accommodation that is dealt with in the statement. Labor believe that that is simply insufficient. We believe that it is insufficient to separate families. I note that the Immigration Detention and Advisory Group, which advises the minister on these questions, has been the author of publicity indicating that that is insufficient. It says that there are no security or other reasons why something like the alternate Woomera detention trial should not be used for whole family groups, intact family groups and family groups with fathers. Our suggested amendment to the Migration Act actually deals with whole family groups; this ministerial statement does not.  
This ministerial statement does not canvass anything further than high-security detention in compounds as we know them, like Baxter and Woomera, and fairly highly secure detention in the form of the alternate Woomera detention trial. No other options are canvassed and, as the minister would be aware, Labor's policy canvasses options like supervised hostel arrangements. Once again, the government's plan is insufficient to meet the needs of children and family members.
At the time of the next election, Australians will have a choice between the government's ad hoc Pacific solution and a better plan to protect Australia and the Australian way. This plan will be announced and advocated by Labor. Liberal moderate members of this House—indeed, moderate members of the National Party and moderate members of the government generally—have a choice to make far earlier than that, though. They have an opportunity next week, when this House debates the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002 and Labor's amendment, to work out what they are prepared to stand for. I say to those Liberal moderates: if your pressure on the government has already resulted in this statement, then that is a small step forward but you should keep the pressure on the government to take a bigger step forward. 
Labor's amendment contains a bigger step forward. It contains legislative certainty so that unaccompanied children will not be held in high-security detention. We will be calling on moderate members of the government to ensure that something as big and as significant as the plight of unaccompanied children is dealt with by legislation with some certainty and security rather than in some other way. We will be calling on them to seriously consider voting for Labor's amendment, given the security that it offers.
I say to moderate members of the government: if you believe, as I do, that it is important to keep family units together and if you believe, as I do, that our nation has learnt some very bitter lessons in the past about the consequences of separating families—and particularly separating children from family members—then we have learned about the importance of family integrity and keeping family members together as a unit. I also say to moderate members of the government: if you believe that fathers are as equal as mothers in a family and if you believe that older brothers are as equal as sisters in a family, then you have to say that the proposal that has been put forward by the minister today is insufficient. In making that assessment, you can be reassured that you are not causing any security issues, because the government's own Immigration Detention and Advisory Group believes that there are no security issues with putting whole family groups in detention accommodation like the alternate Woomera detention trial.
I say to Liberal moderates: if you believe that families should be kept together, then keep the pressure on the government to keep moving forward. Keep the pressure up by indicating that you still intend to support Labor's amendment to the Migration Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 1) 2002, which this House will have an opportunity to vote on as early as next week.
Debate (on motion by Mr Ruddock) adjourned.

name: Latham, Mark, MP
text:
—Today we have seen the true face of the Howard government. We have seen a minister for taxation, the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer, who has been party to tax avoidance of $50,000 in state land tax; a minister for taxation who has consistently misinformed the parliament about the nature of her family company, Endispute, and her involvement with that company; a minister for taxation who has more conflicts of interest than most people have had hot lunches; and, worst of all, a Prime Minister who does nothing about it—a Prime Minister whose only defence is to talk about feminism. Who would have thought that that would be John Howard's final defence? You know it is his last defence when he is talking about feminism—you just do not hear it. It is like the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations talking about child support—you just do not hear it; it is just not credible. 
The Prime Minister has done nothing about this breach of decent ministerial standards. He has done nothing about the clear breaches of his ministerial code of conduct. The Prime Minister is good at talking the language of empathy. Whenever he is in a tight spot politically, whenever something has gone wrong, he says that he is sympathetic to people, that he can emphasise with the cause of battlers in this country. How about a bit of empathy for Australian taxpayers? How about a bit of empathy for Australian taxpayers who fork out $200 billion every year in revenue to this government?
This is the highest taxing government in Australia's history. Forget about Whitlam, forget about Fraser, forget about Hawke and forget about Keating; the Howard government is the highest taxing government in Australia's history. So wouldn't you think the Howard government would have a minister for taxation who sets a good example for other taxpayers? Wouldn't you think the government would have a minister for taxation who is honest, open and transparent and who does the right thing in the payment of her taxes? Wouldn't you think she would set a good example for the honest, hardworking PAYE taxpayers in Australia who face a bigger and growing burden under this government?
The problem we have with the highest taxing government in Australia's history is that it has a Treasurer who has never seen a tax he did not like. That is the problem with Peter Costello, the Treasurer—he has never seen a tax he did not like. There is the gun tax, the sugar tax, the terrorism tax, the Timor tax, a ticket tax, a milk tax and, of course, a goods and services tax. It is a taxathon under this government for everyone bar the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer, Senator Coonan. She entered into an arrangement with her husband, Mr Rogers, to avoid state land tax and capital gains tax. How did they do this? The proposition, the scam, was quite simple. 
In New South Wales you do not pay land tax on your principal place of residence, but you do pay land tax on properties other than your principal place of residence if they are valued at more than $220,000. So Senator Coonan entered into an arrangement with Andrew Rogers to separate their principal places of residence, even though they both live at Rosemont Avenue, Woollahra. Senator Coonan owns 6 Rosemont Avenue, Woollahra. Andrew Rogers owns 16 Paradise Avenue, Pittwater, but it is used as the weekender for Coonan and Rogers. So their scam: for Coonan to say that her principal place of residence is in Woollahra and for Rogers to say that his principal place of residence is in Pittwater—the illusion, the scam, of a married couple living apart, even though every person in Sydney, particularly the high society in the eastern suburbs, knows that this is a scam and a complete falsehood.
Rogers even went as far as enrolling himself at Paradise Avenue, Pittwater, in March 2001. There has been trouble in paradise for him ever since, because he has been caught out. Poor old Andrew Rogers—this former Supreme Court judge, this person the Prime Minister says is of the highest integrity and standards—has been rearranging his life ever since this matter was raised in the Senate last month. A few weeks ago, the financial affairs of Senator Coonan were raised in the Senate and, ever since, this man of high standing has been totally rearranging his life—trying to put the jigsaw puzzle back together retrospectively. He has had to change his enrolment. Last week he decided he would re-enrol at the house at Woollahra. 
Just yesterday Andrew Rogers decided, for the first time in four years, that he would actually pay state land taxes. He is a born-again taxpayer. Rogers is a born-again taxpayer simply because the Labor Party raised in the Senate these matters in relation to Senator Coonan. The truth is that he could not have been in this tax avoidance for four years unless it was by arrangement with Senator Coonan, because there would have been no point in falsely having his principal place of residence at Pittwater unless she had been willing to comply with it and say that her principal place of residence is at Woollahra. So let us not have any of this humbug from the Prime Minister and his barrackers that somehow it is a question of feminism—it is not; it is a question of honesty; it is a question of ministerial standards.
It was given away in the joint statement that was issued by Senator Coonan at 9.30 last night. When the place is going to bed, when the gallery is going to bed, and a statement is issued you know the minister is in deep trouble. What did that statement reveal? It revealed that the Coonans had not paid their land tax for 1999, 2000, 2001 and for all of 2002 up until yesterday—four years of land tax avoidance on their property at Pittwater. But as if it was not bad enough to have a statement at 9.30 last night, under the cover of darkness in the Press Gallery, there was also a special statement from Andrew Rogers. I will read it to the House.
—It was short.
—In fact, it was a very short statement. He said:
I contacted the Office of State Revenue on November 18, 2002 ...
What is special about that date? It is the date on which Senator Coonan's financial affairs were raised in the Senate. The born-again taxpayer discovered honesty and integrity the day these matters in relation to Senator Coonan's financial affairs were raised in the Senate. In his statement, he said:
I contacted the Office of State Revenue—
the first time in four years—
on November 18, 2002 and informed them of my changed arrangements.
He went on:
I received a land tax assessment from the Office of State Revenue on November 29, 2002—
last Friday—
and paid the assessed land tax on December 2, 2002.
Yesterday. So that is the truth of it: he paid the taxes only because Labor raised the matters in the Senate.
If he claims that he lived at Pittwater—and that has been his claim for four years—and that Paradise Avenue, Pittwater, was his principal place of residence, why does he have to pay the taxes? If it is true that Pittwater has been his principal place of residence throughout 2002, no land tax is assessable—no land tax needs to be paid. So this is an admission of guilt—a retrospective admission of guilt. The man of honour and integrity—the born-again taxpayer—is scrambling and trying to put Humpty Dumpty back together again to try to cover up for Senator Coonan. The truth is that they were in it together all the way through. He could only have had this arrangement at Pittwater by arrangement with Senator Coonan, the federal minister for taxation, who collects $200 billion from honest taxpayers around this country. What sort of example is she setting for them? What sort of example does it set for them that the federal minister will not carry her fair share of taxation? What sort of example does it set around this country to have a minister who will not pull her weight in the Australian taxation system?
We know that the Rogers and Coonan story does not stand up. How do we know? His story is just fantastic; it is false, and this was revealed in the Sydney Morning Herald yesterday. Rogers was phoned at the Woollahra house. He said that:
... he lived at the weekender at Pittwater during the Woollahra renovations, and had changed his enrolment accordingly. 
He was then asked when these renovations had taken place. The Herald reported a spokesperson for Senator Coonan as saying:
... the renovations began in September or October 1999 and finished in April 2000, 11 months before Mr Rogers varied his enrolment.
He has got the wrong alibi. He was in the wrong place at the wrong time and he has been caught out. How do we further know that Rogers has always lived at Woollahra and that this tax scam is an absolute falsehood on the Australian people? The neighbours. The same report in the Sydney Morning Herald states:
No one answered the door at the weekender when the Herald called last week. Val Linton-Frost, who lives next door, said it was “very, very rare to see him [Mr Rogers] down there”. Jo Shaw, two doors away, said: “No one lives there permanently. It's a weekender. We rarely see anyone there.”
The greatest act of deceit—and where you need to see the truth of the matter—is in their own profile. The Australian Financial Review profile of Senator Coonan in July this year was entitled `A Taxing Woman'. The profile starts:
Helen Lloyd Coonan is rattling around the kitchen of her house—
in Woollahra, of course—
microwaving dinner for her dog, Helga—
so the dog is doing all right—
while a Handel aria sung by David Hobson floats through a sound system concealed somewhere. Andrew John Rogers—
remember, this is the fellow whose principal place of residence is in Pittwater—
is nibbling a bowl of plump cherries in the adjacent conservatory ...
How the other half lives! You might have plump cherries and conservatories in the electorates of Warringah and Wentworth—the posh suburbs of Sydney—but the ordinary battling taxpayers pay their taxes and don't even get the plump cherries in the conservatory on the way through. In the profile, Rogers chats about the marriage with Coonan, and his great pride in his wife—not in a woman he lives apart from—living in the house in Woollahra. The profile goes on:
As the sun sets through the trees surrounding their big friendly house in Sydney's eastern suburbs ... the couple rib each other about finances.
I bet they did! I bet they ribbed each other about finances, as in, `Helen, isn't it good we're dodging land tax? Isn't it good that we've not only got the plump cherries in the conservatory but we've outsmarted the New South Wales government and we're not paying a single cent over a four-year period in land tax?' I bet you they were ribbing each other. The profile goes on:
Coonan comes to the table, laughing but a tad defensive. “It's great to be comfortable ... [My greatest extravagance] is personal grooming and good wine ... We travel well.
But listen to this concession:
Some moderation is appropriate because it's part of my background ... to be too extravagant can verge on [the] obscene.”
I will tell you what is obscene: a minister who will not pay her taxes and who enters into a false residential arrangement with her husband to avoid paying state land tax. The July profile goes on, with Rogers talking about Coonan:
“We live in each other's skin. We have the same interests: the dog, travel, and people.
Note they said `the dog', not two dogs. There is not a dog in Pittwater and a dog in Woollahra, just `the dog'—who does that remind you of?—`travel and people'. Finally, Rogers and Coonan say:
The weekender at Clareville on Sydney's Pittwater has not been visited this year—
They are condemned by their own words. How do we further know about the tax avoidance? In the annual returns for Endispute, Andrew Rogers, as the company secretary, lists his address at Woollahra. If you look up the Sydney phone book—I should have brought it into the chamber—you see that it says: Andrew Rogers, 6 Rosemont Avenue, Woollahra. He owned up to his guilt as he tried to unscramble the egg last week, telling the Australian Electoral Commission, `Hang on; wait a sec. Labor has raised the matter in the Senate; I had better return my enrolment to Rosemont Avenue, Woollahra.' And then we even have Steve Price, on 2UE. I did an interview with Steve Price this morning. He was very interested in this idea that Rogers lived up at Pittwater, because he said to me that he was talking to Rogers and Coonan at a social function in Sydney last Friday, and they were talking proudly about their home in Woollahra. 
So everyone knows the truth. You do not need to be Sherlock Holmes to work out what has been going on. It is a tax dodge. It is a minister in an arrangement with her husband to avoid land tax on their property at Pittwater. Everyone knows it, apparently bar the Prime Minister. It is no wonder the Prime Minister believes in Santa—and you might as well throw in the Easter Bunny, the Tooth Fairy and the Loch Ness Monster. If the Prime Minister believes for a moment that Senator Coonan has not been avoiding her tax, the next thing he will tell you is that he bumped into Elvis down at the Woden shops the other day. This is a fellow who believes in Santa Claus, and he obviously believes—he is the only person who does—that somehow Andrew Rogers has actually lived at this Pittwater residence. In fact, it is a cover-up. It is a cover-up where one consultant to Clayton Utz is looking after another. Rogers works as a consultant to Clayton Utz—the job that Howard had! You talk about the insiders, the elites, the Liberal Party club: they are all in on it. It is one consultant at Clayton Utz looking after another.
Earlier, you had the Prime Minister saying he had been assured by Rogers, through another person—it sounds like a seance—that Rogers was trying to do the right thing when it came to Senator Coonan's ministerial interest. It does not add up. Land tax and also capital gains tax are being avoided. On the question of capital gains tax on the Pittwater property, today's Sydney Morning Herald reads as follows:
... Mr Rogers told the Herald at the weekend that the property had been bought by a family trust in 1979 and then by him in about 1993.
So the property would have also been eligible for capital gains tax payment when it was sold. Rogers has been trying to avoid that with his false enrolment and his false residential arrangements. Rogers lives at Woollahra. He should pay land tax on the Pittwater property and he should pay capital gains tax when it is sold. It is only by arrangement with Senator Coonan that this matter has come to the House's attention. The senator is damned by the confessions of guilt that have been placed on the table here today. It is only by arrangement with her that this tax avoidance has taken place, and she stands condemned—as does the Prime Minister for failing to uphold decent standards in the parliament, failing to uphold ministerial standards and failing to uphold his own ministerial code of conduct. (Time expired)

name: Abbott, Tony, MP
text:
—The member for Werriwa may well believe what he has just told the House but plainly the opposition does not. If the opposition believed any of this, there would be a censure motion. What we have heard from the member for Werriwa is the censure that wasn't. This was to be the big day when `Latham QC' demonstrated his great forensic skills to this House and more particularly demonstrated his great forensic skills to his own back bench. Having listened to `Latham QC' do his best to his colleagues and his worst to Senator Coonan and to Andrew Rogers, I have this advice for the member for Werriwa: stick to taxi drivers, mate! Taxi drivers apparently can be belted with impunity in New South Wales thanks to the sorry state of law and order in New South Wales under the Carr government. The fact is, the Assistant Treasurer will get a good defence from this government because she has done absolutely nothing wrong.
It has been very interesting watching events unfold in the House this afternoon at question time. First of all, we saw a certain amount of glee from members opposite as they thought, `Aha! Today we're going to have a little bit of sport at the expense of Senator Helen Coonan.' But very soon, as the attack led by `Latham QC' ran into the sands, the looks of glee quickly became looks of terrible gloom as the opposition realised that, yet again, the big attack on the government had foundered; until, as time went by, the member for Werriwa floundered more and more obviously, who should start to perk up? The member for Lilley perked up, the member for Griffith perked up, the member for Melbourne perked up and the whole leadership team—the would-be leadership team—the pygmies in a crowd of dwarfs, all started to perk up as they watched the member for Werriwa's attack turn out to be absolutely nothing at all. 
Let us look at exactly what has been alleged by the member for Werriwa and, at various stages, by the Leader of the Opposition. It is interesting how the member for Werriwa has been on a total and utter frolic of his own today, supported only by the Leader of the Opposition, who is too weak to resist him. What did the member for Werriwa allege? He alleged that former Justice Andrew Rogers was falsely enrolled. The fact is, Andrew Rogers leads a peripatetic existence. He is often overseas. He is often interstate. He does not have to be constantly at Clareville to be legitimately enrolled there. He alleged that Andrew Rogers had not paid his land tax. Andrew Rogers has paid his land tax. He has told us that. The member for Werriwa accepts that Rogers has paid his land tax. He said that Rogers did not pay capital gains tax. The most basic lesson that `Latham QC' should have known is that you only pay capital gains tax when there is a capital gain, when there is a sale, when something is disposed of. There has been no sale, no disposal, no realised capital gain and therefore no capital gains tax liability. Go back to school, `Latham QC'!
We have had this outrageous statement repeated time and time again—sometimes in the guise of a rhetorical question—that Senator Coonan has somehow witnessed a false enrolment declaration. That is utterly, completely and shamefully false. Members opposite ought to be utterly embarrassed about perpetrating this vicious lie against a decent and good minister of the Crown in this government.
We then have the constant claim that Senator Coonan has somehow made a false disclosure. We had the member for Werriwa at the dispatch box waving around various documents which purported to be receipts or invoices from some company that was allegedly trading midyear. So what? Senator Coonan disposed of her interest. She completely and most properly disposed of her interest in this company as soon as she became a minister of the Crown, not as she was utterly required to do under the Prime Minister's guidelines but simply for more abundant propriety and adherence to the principles of good government and honesty that this government has practised.
Then of course there was the terrible sin that this company—Endispute, I think its name was—was still registered at a home where Senator Coonan resides. Why should it not be at the place of residence of her independent adult son? Her son is a practising lawyer, an associate with a law firm. Why should it not continue to be registered where Senator Helen Coonan's son lives?
Today we have seen an attack by the member for Werriwa, who has no conception whatsoever of modern Australian families. He has no conception whatsoever of the reality of modern life, that husbands and wives can have an independent business existence or that adult children can have a life and an opinion of their own. We on this side believe that women should be judged on their merits, not on their husbands. That is the shameful thing that Labor has been perpetrating here today and the utter humiliation that the member for Werriwa has visited upon the would-be proud feminists of the ALP. Where was the member for Fremantle? I think she was boycotting the shameful and embarrassing proceedings perpetrated by the member for Werriwa and the Leader of the Opposition today. Why was the member for Throsby complicit in this terrible attack on a modern independent Australian working woman? Why was the member for Lalor not protesting against this embarrassing attack on a modern independent Australian working woman?
The simple truth is that this government is not responsible for Andrew Rogers; Andrew Rogers is responsible for Andrew Rogers. Helen Coonan is not responsible for Andrew Rogers any more than Andrew Rogers is responsible for Helen Coonan—they are independent people. They are adults with lives of their own. Why should members opposite come into this chamber and claim that wives or husbands are each other's chattels? That is a 19th century, mid-Victorian attitude. 
—That is what it is like down at trade hall.
—That is right. That is probably exactly what it is like. It is the ALP boys club in action—the shameful ALP boys club which has done such terrible things to the careers of so many decent women who made the mistake of joining the Australian Labor Party and of thinking that they were going to get a fair go there. The most that Senator Coonan is guilty of is an inadvertent mistake. People should not be hung, drawn and quartered on the basis of a few inadvertent mistakes. I recall that members of this parliament, members of good standing, people of high integrity, have made honest mistakes and inadvertent misdisclosures. I recall the member for Batman making an inadvertent misdisclosure. I would be the last person to impugn the member for Batman's integrity and honesty. He is a man of great distinction. The member for Barton was guilty of an inadvertent misdisclosure. These things happen, and we do not hold them against members opposite. Members opposite should have the decency, the sense of honour, the sense of proportion and the sense of place to extend the same benefit of the doubt to members on this side that we typically extend to them.
Senator Coonan's real crime in the eyes of the member for Werriwa is twofold. Firstly, she is successful and, secondly, she is a  woman. And the boys club over there just do not like it. That is why they come into this parliament sooling, dribbling and salivating. Anyone would think it was a taxidriver that the member for Werriwa had discovered in his late night ravings and rantings and peregrinations around the city. Instead he has now sicked himself on Senator Coonan. All his malice and all the hatred that he so carefully nurtures—the hatred that he believes is the highest virtue of politics—are now turned in the direction of Senator Coonan. I have to say: is there anyone that the member for Werriwa does not have a vendetta against? Is there anyone that he likes? Is there anyone that he has a good word for? I see the member for Lilley coming into the chamber.
—He's very happy. It's a happy day.
—He is very happy because he has seen the member for Werriwa end up with an enormous amount of egg on his face after the member for Werriwa spent the best part of the last fortnight badmouthing the member for Lilley all around the press gallery. The member for Lilley was quite clever—he of all the pretenders to the throne has done nothing to lift his profile. Then the member for Werriwa gets his mate Alan Ramsey to write an endorsement of the member for Lilley, and the rest is history. We all know what the member for Werriwa has been trying to do. Is there anyone that the member for Werriwa does not hate? Is there anyone he is not running some kind of vendetta against? I was amused to read in the Strewth column today of the member for Werriwa's former friend Peter Botsman, the former director of the Evatt Foundation and one of the real intellectuals of the Labor Party. They talk about the sage of Werriwa; Peter Botsman really knows what he is talking about. He is a real thinker. Peter Botsman's books are worth reading; they are readable—unlike anything that is produced by the member for Werriwa.
Peter Botsman made the mistake of telling the truth about the member for Werriwa. The member for Werriwa then engaged in a vicious, partisan, untrue campaign of lies against him, including, according to the Strewth column, a whole lot of obscene references to mateship and various other things. He is now out on his ear, as is just about everyone else who has ever crossed paths with the member for Werriwa. It is interesting, isn't it? 
We have seen a serious Labor leader win, it has to be admitted, a great Labor victory this weekend. The reason Steve Bracks was able to win a significant victory was that, above all else, he comes across as a decent, honest man who is prepared to give even people he does not agree with a fair go. That is how Steve Bracks comes across to the voters of Victoria, and what a contrast it is to this Bonnie and Clyde performance from Simon Crean, the Leader of the Opposition, and the member for Werriwa. Both of them are united in hatred and in spite. They are vicious against success and hate filled against successful women. Nothing could better highlight the contrast between a real Labor leader and what the ALP has in this parliament than the performance today from the Leader of the Opposition and the member for Werriwa. The member for Werriwa is the Aunty Jack of Australian politics. If you do not like him, he rips your bloody arms off—that is his view. But I have to say that his big day out has been a complete flop. He has set his leadership ambitions back many months if not forever. We are not going to hear any more on this matter—and I will make this a promise—because nothing wrong has been done. There has been no impropriety. There has been no breach of the law. There has been no breach of the Prime Minister's guidelines. Senator Helen Coonan and her husband are honest people. (Time expired)

name: Cox, David, MP
text:
—I think that performance by the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations is a bit rich, given some of the frolics that he has been off on in the last couple of years. 
One of the first acts of this Prime Minister on coming to office was to release A guide on key elements of ministerial responsibility. What a piece of hubris it was and how quickly he came to rue the day that he ever released it. First he discovered that many of his ministers were not capable of managing their affairs in accordance with that set of guidelines, that code, then, when he discovered that he himself was not capable of managing his own affairs in relation to that code, standards became double standards and responsibility became convenience.
The first person to fall foul of Howard's code was the hapless Senator Herron, who was found practising medicine in contravention of the requirement `not to engage in any professional practice or in the daily work of any business'. Not unreasonably, if people are drawing a ministerial salary for looking after a difficult portfolio, they should be required to attend to it full time. Herron was forced to give up his surgery practice but not his portfolio. So from the start a breach of the code did not necessarily mean the sack.
The first of the few ministers who have actually lost their job for breaching the code was Jim Short, then Assistant Treasurer. He was forced to resign after he approved an operating licence for an ANZ Bank subsidiary when he had shares in the ANZ Bank. This had contravened the requirement for ministers to `divest themselves of all shares and similar interests in any company or business involved in the area of their portfolio responsibilities'. Jim Short was rewarded for taking his medicine and leaving parliament quietly by being made Australia's executive director at the European Bank of Reconstruction and Development, which happens to be in London.
John Moore, the industry minister, was next to transgress with a $100,000 shareholding in Bligh Ventures Ltd, a technology investment company, contravening the requirement to divest business interests in any area of portfolio responsibility, and a controlling interest in Ralston Pty Ltd, a share-trading company, in contravention of the express prohibition of operating as share traders. Despite these two breaches, the Prime Minister spared John Moore. An exemption from the code for stockbrokers perhaps, Queenslanders maybe—no, party powerbrokers, I think. The `party powerbroker principle'!
Not so lucky was Brian Gibson, Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, who exempted a Boral subsidiary from certain provisions of the Corporations Law. He was not a party powerbroker—he went. Small business minister Geoff Prosser knew something about small business: he owned three shopping centres and took an active interest in running them while a minister, in contravention of the requirement not to engage in the daily work of any business. He was not a powerbroker—he got the sack.
Ministers were required to `resign directorships in public companies'—but not the Prime Minister. Mr Howard was a director of the Menzies Institute, a public company. The Prime Minister could not live up to his own code. He resigned the directorship. Flexibility was required. The `Prime Minister principle': prime ministers are exempt from the code. 
There were six critical incidents and three resignations in a little over a year. The code literally went out the window on the next one. Warwick Parer, the Minister for Resources and Energy, was found to have, through a family trust, an $8 million share in a coalmine and interests in many other resource stocks. Howard allowed Parer to transfer the assets of his family trust to his children, ignoring the explicit provision that `the transfer of interests to a family member or to a nominee or trust is not an acceptable form of divestment'. Later it was also found that the holding company of the Parer family trust had purchased shares in the original Telstra float at a time when Parer was a director of the holding company and held eight of the nine shares—in contravention of a specific prime ministerial proscription on ministers purchasing Telstra shares within 90 days of the float.
Notwithstanding the treatment of Short, Gibson and Prosser—and for no other explicable reason than that Parer was a close friend of the Prime Minister—a way round all that had to be found. The `mates principle'! Of course, we should not forget the `brother principle' when the Prime Minister had to bail out his brother's company.
After almost a year of controversy over Parer, the Prime Minister quietly tabled a revised code allowing ministers to transfer interests to independent family members and control of interests to an outside professional nominee or trust. If the minister can't keep the rules, change them—the `flexibility principle'! This change has turned out to be very fortuitous for Senator Coonan: it has allowed her to transfer her shares in Endispute to her son.
After the Parer case there were no standards. The Parliamentary Secretary for Industry, Science and Resources, Warren Entsch, had a company called Cape York Concrete that was found to have won a $175,500 contract from the RAAF.
—Bob the builder!
—Bob the builder, yes. He had failed to disclose his directorship of the company in his parliamentary declaration of interests. Entsch was also found to have a conflict of interest in pressing the CSIRO to clean up an area near a Cairns property he owned and advocating a major development nearby. The Prime Minister took no action: the `don't give the opposition a scalp principle'! When the Parliamentary Secretary to Cabinet, Senator Heffernan, failed to disclose his business interests and directorships, the Prime Minister took no action. The powerbroker principle again. 
When, as Acting Minister for Communications, Peter McGauran announced a moratorium on Internet gambling and took a bill through the House to implement it—having failed to declare a pecuniary interest in a competing gambling industry, poker machines—the Prime Minister failed to act. The `National Party principle', something that reigned supreme in the Fraser years. When the Minister for Employment Services, Mal Brough, was exposed promoting training courses which were actually being run as party fundraisers, the Prime Minister failed to act. The National Party principle or the `if he's game enough to do that, he ought to be able to get away with it principle'!
—Mal Brough is in the Liberal Party.
—Oh, is he? Then of course there was the telecard affair. On 10 October 2000 the Canberra Times revealed that the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, Peter Reith, had run up a bill of $50,000 on his taxpayer-funded telecard. The minister had been informed about the bill more than a year earlier. Mr Reith was forced to admit he had given the telecard number and personal identification number to his son. He had not used the card since 1994.
After a departmental investigation, Reith claimed only $950 corresponded to calls made by his son. He repaid this amount but refused to accept responsibility for the rest, despite contrary legal advice. Only public pressure, not the Prime Minister's intervention, forced him to repay the $50,000. The Prime Minister had backed Reith throughout the affair and took no action against him. This was under the principle that, if you are big and ugly enough, you can get away with anything. The reward for the Prime Minister was that Reith took responsibility for what the Prime Minister said he was not told about the children overboard affair—the principle that, if you have no principles, you can do anything. That, unfortunately, is the environment in which ministers in the Howard government now operate. 
Events over the last couple of weeks in relation to the Minister for Revenue, Senator Coonan, have made rather a mockery of the requirement that:
Ministers must be honest in their public dealings and should not intentionally mislead the Parliament or the public. Any misconception caused inadvertently should be corrected at the earliest opportunity.
The Minister for Revenue has made rather a lot of misleading statements in the last couple of weeks. In that time she has been scrambling to tidy up the loose ends of the issues that have been raised about her.
First there was the failure of Endispute to lodge an ASIC return confirming that she had ceased to be a director. It should have been done within 14 days last January; it has now been done. She told the Senate quite categorically on 19 November that Endispute is a shelf company. Today, after the member for Werriwa produced invoices in the House showing it had been trading recently, she was forced to qualify her earlier statement. She now says it was a shelf company when she divested her shares to her son.
Then there is the discrepancy in her declaration of pecuniary interests, in which she described her residence at Woollahra as an investment property. This was explained as a typographical error by her personal assistant. First we had core and non-core promises; now discrepancies between pecuniary interest statements can be described as typos. There seems to be a lot of confusion around the residential status of various pieces of property: principal places of residence, weekenders, investment properties. It is all a bit confused and it certainly has not been corrected at the earliest opportunity or at all. Several years of land taxes were paid only yesterday. The minister is scrambling to regularise all her arrangements. The Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations says she should not be hung for a few inadvertent mistakes. She will be. (Time expired)

name: Pyne, Chris, MP
text:
—Today during question time when the Prime Minister tabled the electoral enrolments of Andrew Rogers in Pittwater and then Woollahra I looked at the member for Werriwa and the blood drained from his face because he suddenly realised that the case that he had built around electoral fraud and potential tax avoidance had completely come crashing down. I am sure the idea that went through his mind at that time was: `Have I been set up? Have my mates Swanie and Ruddie actually set me up with this? Who came up with this idea? Was it the tactics committee? Am I on the tactics committee? Who came up with the suggestion that I should pursue Helen Coonan's electoral fraud?' There is no other explanation. Sloppy research has not been a hallmark of the member for Werriwa's political career.
So what is the explanation for this embarrassing own goal? There has not been such an embarrassing own goal in many years in this parliament. For an opposition to make gross calumnies against a minister of the Crown and not have the evidence in front of them—not have the electoral enrolments themselves when they were claiming that she had witnessed them—is an act of gross, sloppy research. I can only believe that the member for Lilley and maybe the member for Griffith, who is usually a decent person, got together and thought, `He's doing too well. Crikey's saying that the member for Werriwa should be the Leader of the Opposition. We'll have to take him down. We have taken Emerson down.
