We managed to convince Emerson it was a great idea to send around an email to all the parliamentary caucus saying that the Labor Party was not going anywhere, so we got rid of Emerson.' Not that he was ever in the race from this side of the House.
If I were the member for Jagajaga, the member for Melbourne or the member for Brand, I would be starting to seriously wonder whether Francis Urquhart is operating in the background of the Labor Party, maybe out of the chief whip's office, to make sure that all the contenders for Labor leadership are fixed up one by one. 
—Madam Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order on relevance. The matter of public importance is about ministerial standards. Maybe the member for Sturt could spend even 15 seconds defending Senator Coonan; even 15 seconds attending relevantly to the matter of public importance.
 (Ms Gambaro)—I thank the member for Werriwa for his point of order and I ask the member for Sturt to come back to the point.
—I will be getting to the defence of Senator Coonan very shortly but I could not resist pointing out what is actually going on in the Labor Party on the frontbench. My friend from Lateline, the member for Werriwa, has so tragically been cut down today. After two weeks of trying to get rid of the member for Lilley, Lilley has finally struck him down today; cut him down in his prime. He might even have been working with Peter Botsman; I am not sure. But he is finished. In terms of his leadership credentials, the member for Werriwa is looking very sad today.
Let us turn to the defence of Senator Coonan. Senator Coonan is a very good friend of mine. In fact, I used to share a house with her here in Canberra until she was put into the ministry. She has been the subject of a very unfair, unsubstantiated and very serious allegation; a smear campaign against her by not only the member for Werriwa but many other members of the Labor Party, particularly in the Senate. It is an example of the gutter politics that one expects from the ALP when all else is failing. Simon Crean's leadership is 18 per cent in the Newspoll and suddenly the Labor Party start grasping for straws. They cannot debate us on health policy, they cannot debate us on border protection, they cannot hold a candle to us on economic management. So what do they do? They send the member for Werriwa out there and rather than breaking poor old Mustafa Bashir's arm he will deal with Senator Coonan and take her on. Unfortunately, it has all blown up in his face, like one of those cigars that the Marx Brothers used to give to people.
Senator Coonan has not breached the ministerial code of conduct. Senator Coonan has not been involved in any tax avoidance. Senator Coonan has not been involved in any electoral enrolment irregularity. More importantly, the allegations being made against Senator Coonan are actually all directed at Andrew Rogers. Good former Justice Andrew Rogers is really the person who the Labor Party are making these allegations about. By association, we are supposed to believe that Senator Coonan has in fact breached the ministerial code of conduct, been involved in tax avoidance and been involved in electoral fraud.
This is like medieval Europe or even 19th century Victorian England, as the Leader of the House pointed out. I cannot believe that in 2002 members of the House of Representatives are arguing that the wife of a person like Andrew Rogers is somehow responsible for everything Andrew Rogers does. This goes to the very heart of what the ALP really believes. Despite all the business about quotas and bringing women into the ALP—it helps, of course, if you are married to a current ALP member or if you are the daughter or son of an ALP member, but I will put that to one side—this says that the real ALP has not changed at all. The ALP is still a boys club. Tammany Hall or Sussex Street are still running the ALP, and the women are really just chattels. They are only there as window dressing on the front bench and the back bench of the ALP around Australia. They are not really making their own decisions—they could not be! Helen Coonan could not seriously make her own decisions; she is a woman and she is married—
—To a man!
—to a man, so she must be a chattel of her husband. As a consequence, she must be maligned in this terrible way by the member for Werriwa. This is more Calwell than Whitlam. I thought the Labor Party had moved on. 
I turn to the allegations specifically. There are four of them. One is that Senator Coonan breached the ministerial code of conduct through her involvement with Endispute. Senator Coonan divested herself of her holding in Endispute and passed it to her son, who is an adult—he is 25. A new part of the ALP's policy is apparently that you are not an adult at 25, which will come as a nasty shock to all the people with drivers licences, who can be called up to the army and other things. Apparently Helen Coonan's son is not capable of making his own decisions. She divested herself of her involvement in Endispute, so of course she was not in breach of the ministerial code of conduct.  
The allegation is that capital gains tax was not paid. That is just sloppy research again, member for Werriwa. You know as well as anybody does, I hope—maybe the Leader of the Opposition does not know, but I would have thought you would have known—that capital gains tax does not apply until you realise a capital gain. No capital gain had been realised. If the property was bought in 1979 and sold in 1993, and it is still in the hands of the person who bought it in 1993 and has not been sold, you know as well as I do that no capital gain has been realised, and there could have been no capital gains tax avoidance.
—Maybe that is their new policy!
—Maybe that is it! Maybe you pay the capital gains tax up front! Unrealised capital gains tax is the new Labor policy! Is that what it is? 
The next allegation is that land tax was not paid. The member for Werriwa himself admitted that the land tax has been paid on the property in Pittwater. More importantly, Senator Coonan has no beneficial interest in the Pittwater property. She owns a property in Woollahra, lucky person. He owns a property in Pittwater, lucky person. But that does not make her responsible for what happens at the house in Pittwater. It has nothing to do with her. She has no beneficial interest. To suggest she does is to suggest that she, as in medieval England, is just a chattel of Andrew Rogers. Knowing them both as well as I do, I am sure that Andrew Rogers would find the idea of Helen Coonan being his chattel at any time very amusing.
The final allegation is that Senator Coonan was involved in enrolment fraud. This is a great call from the Labor Party, isn't it? As a former Chair of the Joint Standing Committee on Electoral Matters, the idea of the ALP accusing anybody on this side of the House of being involved in electoral enrolment fraud strikes me as quite amusing. There is no evidence of a bodgie enrolment. The so-called evidence that Senator Coonan witnessed a bodgie enrolment blew up in the Labor Party's face in the most spectacular fashion in question time today. Senator Coonan did not witness any enrolment change from Pittwater to Woollahra or Woollahra to Pittwater. For the Labor Party to claim that they have any moral high ground on electoral enrolment is amusing. One thinks of the Shepherdson inquiry; the loss of Jim Elder; the loss of Grant Musgrove; the loss of Mike Kaiser, the leading light of the Queensland Labor Party; the jailing of Karen Ehrmann; and the suspended sentences handed down to a number of other Queensland ALP figures, for allegations of electoral enrolment fraud. The idea that Labor is in any position to move such a motion amuses me immensely. 
In conclusion, the hypocrisy of the Labor Party in moving a motion that says anything about ministerial standards says that they have a lot of front. You have to give them that: they have a lot of front.
—More front than Mark Foys!
—More front than Cox-Foys.
—I said Mark Foys.
—It is Mark Foys in Sydney; in Adelaide it is Cox-Foys—or Harris Scarfe's. More front than Harris Scarfe's in Adelaide!
—What about Carmen Lawrence?
—Carmen Lawrence; Graham Richardson; Alan Griffin; Robert Tickner; Ros Kelly, the most famous one of all—the list of ministerial casualties in the Keating government means that the idea that Labor can tell us anything about ministerial standards is grossly hypocritical. I condemn them for this MPI and put my full support behind the Minister for Revenue and Assistant Treasurer.
 (Ms Gambaro)—Order! The discussion is now concluded.

Time allotted—remaining private Members' business time.

First Government Member speaking—5 minutes.
Other Members—5 minutes each.

The Committee determined that consideration of this matter should continue on a future day.

name: Andrews, Kevin, MP
text:
—I move:
That the requested amendment be made.
I am pleased to note that the function of the Professional Services Review continues to attract strong bipartisan support and that the proposed amendments have the support of the opposition. This process of peer review is an important element in the overall administration of Medicare in ensuring the continuation of appropriate practice by medical practitioners. In respect of the Cleft Lip and Cleft Palate Scheme, the government is pleased to accept the amendment as proposed by the Senate. The amendment adds to the government's initiative to lift the age limit from 21 to 28 to ensure a sufficient time period to accommodate the facial growth of all patients. The amendment recognises that, in some circumstances, it may be necessary to repair previous reconstructive surgery performed under the scheme in connection with the condition after the age of 28. Should this be required, this can now occur. I therefore commend the amendment and the Health Insurance Amendment (Professional Services Review and Other Matters) Bill 2002 to the House.
Question agreed to.

—Mr Speaker has received a message from the Senate acquainting the House that the Senate has considered the bill for an act to amend the law relating to social security and for related purposes and has divided the bill into two bills: a bill for an act to amend the law relating to social security and for related purposes, the Family and Community Services Legislation Amendment (Australians Working Together and other 2001 Budget Measures) Bill 2002, consisting of clauses 1, 2 (as amended) and 3, schedules 1 (as amended), 4 (renumbered 2) and 5 (renumbered 3), the words of enactment and the title of the original bill; and a bill for an act to amend the law relating to social security and for related purposes, the Family and Community Services Legislation Amendment (Australians Working Together and other 2001 Budget Measures) Bill (No. 2) 2002, consisting of schedules 2 (as amended), 3, 6 (as amended) and 7 of the original bill, renumbered 1, 2, 3 and 4, respectively, words of enactment and a title. 
The Senate returns the Family and Community Services Legislation Amendment (Australians Working Together and other 2001 Budget Measures) Bill (No. 2) 2002 as divided and incorporating the Senate's amendments, and requests the concurrence of the House of Representatives in the action taken by the Senate and in the amendments made by the Senate.
The Senate also acquaints the House that further consideration of the Family and Community Services Legislation Amendment (Australians Working Together and other 2001 Budget Measures) Bill 2002 has been made an order of the day for the next day of sitting.

name: Jenkins, Harry (The DEPUTY SPEAKER)
text:
—Before the House proceeds with any action in relation to this message, I wish to draw the attention of the House to the fact that the Senate has purported to divide the original bill into two bills and purported to make certain amendments. The Senate has transmitted one of the proposed bills to the House and has not completed its consideration of the second proposed bill. The Senate has requested the concurrence of the House in the action taken by the Senate and in amendments made by the Senate.
The House will recall that, on 29 August this year, in relation to the Research Involving Embryos and Prohibition of Human Cloning Bill 2002, the Speaker advised the House that there was no constraint upon the house in which a bill originated considering a proposal to divide a bill. The Speaker reminded the House that, on two occasions since 1995, the Senate had requested the House to consider a proposal to divide a House bill. The position of the House has been that the division of a bill in the house in which the bill did not originate was not desirable. Also, I understand that there may be grounds for the Senate action in purporting to divide a House bill being considered to provide the first stage of a failure to pass a bill for the purposes of section 57 of the Constitution. On the two previous occasions on which a Senate message purported to divide a bill originating in the House, the House did not consider the message seeking the concurrence of the House in the Senate action. It rests with the House as to whether it will consider the Senate message on this occasion.
debate_title: <title>FAMILY AND COMMUNITY SERVICES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT (AUSTRALIANS WORKING TOGETHER AND OTHER 2001 BUDGET MEASURES) BILL 2002</title>

name: Anthony, Larry, MP
text:
—I move:
That the House:
(1)	endorses the statement of the Deputy Speaker concerning the Family and Community Services Legislation Amendment (Australians Working Together and other 2001 Budget Measures) Bill 2002 and Senate message No. 159;
(2)	declines to consider Senate message No. 159; and
(3)	requests the Senate to reconsider the Family and Community Services Legislation Amendment (Australians Working Together and other 2001 Budget Measures) Bill 2002 as originally transmitted to the Senate by House of Representatives' message No. 77 of 30 May 2002.
The government will not accept the splitting of the Family and Community Services Legislation Amendment (Australians Working Together and other 2001 Budget Measures) Bill 2002 by the Senate. The bill as originally introduced is a spending bill and the government will not let the opposition parties cherry pick the measures in the bill that are most beneficial and leave out other parts of the package. All that has been achieved by the Senate in adopting this approach is to delay the start of these beneficial measures. This point was clearly made in the Senate by the Minister for Family and Community Services. 
The bill will be going back to the Senate unsplit and the Senate will have the opportunity to reconsider its position. The point has been made on various occasions that the measures contained in the bill are part of the overall welfare reform package that this government has been developing consistent with the McClure report. The bill represents one step on the path of the long-term whole of government approach to welfare reform. This is a bill in which the government wants to spend more money on welfare recipients, not by giving them more money but by investing in them and giving them greater opportunities. I urge the Senate to keep these facts in mind when it reconsiders the bill.
The opposition have made a great deal about the need to make changes to the breaching process, and I would like to make a few comments about that. First of all, I stress that the government share concerns about the potential impact of breaching on vulnerable job seekers. That is why we have done a lot over the last year or so to ensure that the safeguards that are in the system are for those non-compliances beyond their control or are fully utilised. In particular, Centrelink has become a lot better at identifying vulnerable job seekers. This work was acknowledged by the Ombudsman in his recent report on the administration of breaching.
Further, we have already significantly reduced penalties. In July this year, we introduced policy changes that have more than halved the penalties for many breaches. These changes provide a protection for the vulnerable job seekers but also maintain the deterrent for non-job seekers. It is premature to be talking about the need for changes to these recently introduced modified breaching processes. The government does not intend to make changes to Newstart and Youth Allowance breaching provisions until it has had the opportunity to make a full assessment of the impact of these changes. The government does not accept the Senate amendment to split the AWT bill and will be returning the bill to the Senate for further consideration.

name: Swan, Wayne, MP
text:
—I rise to speak on the government's motion not to assent to the Senate's decision to split the Family and Community Services Legislation Amendment (Australians Working Together and other 2001 Budget Measures) Bill 2002. This is truly a historic moment in the life of this parliament. Here is a government that has vandalised its own bill. It is no wonder Senator Vanstone is now called `Senator Vandalstone', because the only positive measures left out of the tragedy of what was supposed to be a positive welfare reform process in this country over the last 3½ years have now been junked by this gutless minister.
Those opposite come into this House and say that they will not pass some positive measures which the Senate has put into the bill, because it does not suit their political purposes. They want to use the unemployed of this country as hostages in that process. We in the opposition will not accept that; we will not accept that political blackmail. When this government talks the rhetoric of welfare reform, it should talk the rhetoric of rewarding work over welfare. Nothing goes to the heart of rewarding work over welfare more than the working credit. That is part of the very measures that were passed in total by the Senate and which the government is refusing to pass in this House today. They are measures that could go through immediately and be of immediate benefit to the unemployed people of this country.
It just shows how far you will run from genuine welfare reform, how far you will run from rewarding work over welfare, and how far you will go to avoid a genuine debate in this community about making the penalty regime in the Social Security Act fairer for all Australians. When it comes down to it, what you believe in is providing incentives to those on very high incomes and punishment to those on low incomes. That is what it boils down to and that is why Senator Vanstone should hang her head in shame. That is why she is known as `Senator Vandalstone', and that is why, Minister, you are totally gutless. You will not stand up for the people who deserve the beneficial measures contained in the bill, which could be easily passed in this parliament today. 
The bill being considered, and which may be passed today and become law, would reintroduce the work credit, introduce a numeracy and literacy supplement and set up a legal framework for the Personal Support Program. That is all that remains of a positive program of welfare reform. That is all that remains from the McClure process. That is all that remains after 3½ years of rhetoric from this government. And it has now been proven to be empty rhetoric, because Senator Vanstone let the cat out of the bag in the Senate when she said, `The budget is going into deficit. We don't want to spend the money on the working credit any more.' It is $430 million over four years and you are walking away. Senator Vanstone had the hide, the obscenity, when she talked about that in the Senate, to get up say, `It is either the unemployed on the one hand or drought stricken farmers on the other.' That is what she said—she let the cat out of the bag. 
The highest taxing government in this country's history now has a budget problem, and those who are going to suffer are those who are out there working casually or part time; they are the ones who should receive the benefit of the working credit, which is worth $1,000. These are the same people who are continually abused in this House by the Minister for Employment Services, the Minister for Employment and Workplace Relations and the Minister for Children and Youth Affairs. They have double standards all right—double standards all the way through. What we are witnessing here is nothing more than a squalid political tactic so that the government can renege on its commitment to the unemployed and junk the money for the working credit. That is exactly what this is all about.
How extraordinary. I do not know how many times this could possibly have occurred in the last 100 years of political history: the government actually brings a bill back to the House of Representatives and junks its own positive measures. That is what it is doing. I tell you what: what you have done will not go unnoticed in the community. It is just extraordinary that the government can come in here and pretend that this is nothing other than some form of craven savings measure on their part—nothing more than that at all.
The government's refusal points to the fact that it is not committed to genuine welfare reform. It is not committed to rewarding work over welfare. It is simply trying to find a way out of not spending this money. Splitting the bill is not cherry picking, as the minister attempted to say. Other elements of the initial bill, particularly participation requirements of parents and mature age, remain in the Senate, where a resolution of points of difference may continue. They have not been opposed outright, though key points of difference do need to be resolved. Labor is firmly of the view that the noncontentious elements that are with the House should be passed immediately because they are all beneficial. There is no disagreement, so why don't we get on with it? Why don't we get on with rewarding work over welfare? We will not get on with it because the government wants to make savings. There is simply no reason to delay these measures while discussions continue on the other elements of the bill.
The work credit, in particular, requires substantial system changes by Centrelink, and I am sure that that agency would welcome the certainty that would come with the immediate passage of this legislation. Then there are changes to the personal support program, a program which was scheduled to commence on 1 July, nearly six months ago. Let us not forget: this is the second time that the government has frustrated the introduction of the working credit, not the first; it was delayed previously in a budget some time ago. Now we have this new phoney tactic of delaying working credits so that the government does not have to spend the money.
These measures should be passed now, and the failure of the government to do so indicates just how barren it is and to what lengths it will go to deceive the Australian public and, particularly, to do the wrong thing by vulnerable Australians and the unemployed. There is simply no reason not to pass these measures now. The argument that somehow the House cannot deal with a split bill is a nonsense, and the minister opposite knows it. Indeed, the principle was adopted by the House just recently in relation to embryo research and cloning—and moved by none other than the Prime Minister. So we should be able to deal substantively with this bill today. A split bill is no different from a bill that returns from the Senate with amendments which omit certain parts—no different at all. So let us get rid of all of that nonsense that we had from the minister. 
However, in this instance, the other parts of the bill are not dead; they are still ready for discussion in the Senate as soon as the government is willing. Labor did not come to the decision to split the bill lightly. We gave the government ample opportunity to work through our points of disagreement on the other parts of the bill. But at the last minute the government refused to discuss any detailed changes. The government led us to believe that it was seriously considering amendments to the other parts of the bill. It encouraged us to talk to it and then at the last minute, around midnight the night before, it suddenly cancelled all discussions. Why did the government do that? Because it got the message from the Treasurer and from Senator Vanstone that it was out of money and the people who were going to pay would be the beneficiaries of the working credit. That is how it came about.
We gave the government plenty of opportunity. Senator Vanstone has been saying in the Senate that somehow we were not talking. That is not so. We were talking, and the officials over there know we were talking. We were led to believe that there were going to be realistic discussions about the amendments. But then the political fix came in and the government decided it was going to go down the road that it has always gone down: when in doubt or in political trouble, go out and vilify the unemployed, imply that they are all work shy, do not worry about the role of incentives in the system, and save the money—that was the motivation: save the money. But Labor remains ready and willing to discuss the detailed amendments that are on the table.
The changes proposed by Labor are moderate; they involve additional safeguards for the government's proposed changes regarding parents and mature age. These are fairly straightforward. Indeed, up until the government's decision not to play ball, we believed that it was viewing our amendments favourably. In addition, Labor are keen to engage the government in a debate to bring about changes to improve the breaching regime that job seekers and these new groups will be subject to—because we all know that Senator Vanstone has this shoot-first ask-questions-later fining policy—this shoot-first ask-questions-later penalty regime. We know it is like that. It is completely indiscriminate, which is why something like 40 per cent of these breaches are overturned on appeal. There is clearly a substantial need to put in some essential protections for people, and that is why the sector commissioned the Pearce review. We have put forward reasonable amendments based on the Pearce review to give people some reasonable protections in these circumstances. We remain keen to pursue that objective and will continue to do so. Labor will continue to engage the government in any debate to bring about changes to improve the penalty regime that job seekers and these new groups will be subject to—changes to improve fairness and compliance.
I say in the strongest possible terms: these changes have absolutely nothing to do with going soft, as Minister Vanstone claims. They have absolutely nothing at all to do with that. Changes that have been canvassed in the amendment moved in the second reading debate in the Senate could very well lead to an increase in job seekers doing the right thing, improving their job prospects and, ultimately, gaining employment and moving off benefits. But, no, the government is not interested in genuine reform; it never has been. That is why there has been this whole process, starting with Senator Newman and all those proposals she had hidden in the bottom drawer. You might recall those proposals; they cut the benefit to disability support pensioners—a benefit which has turned up in another bill that has been named a reforming bill but which is nothing more than another crude cost-cutting measure. All those proposals are still there. And this government wonders why we remain suspicious of what it is really up to. 
The only one that is going soft in this business is the government. It is not interested in rewarding work over welfare; it is just interested now in not spending the money. That will bring to an end this whole false and phoney process it has had in place of pretending to reform the system. Really, it is not doing that at all. It is just leaving the welfare trap in place because it is not prepared to make the necessary investment in people. To sum up, this bill should pass the House today and become law. Labor urge the government to start talking about the detail of Labor's amendments and other parts of the bill. Labor have a detailed position on the table for the government to respond to. There is simply no place for this bloody-minded attitude from this government. Labor will oppose the motion and we shall reserve our right to split the bill in the Senate again.

name: McFarlane, Jann, MP
text:
—I rise today to speak on the Family and Community Services Legislation Amendment (Australians Working Together and other 2001 Budget Measures) Bill 2002. I support the shadow minister, the member for Lilley, in calling for the splitting of the bill. The bill has two significant aspects, a positive aspect and a negative aspect. The positive aspects in this bill deliver $900 million in assistance to Australian families and the long-term unemployed. The government is to be commended for these positive aspects. The negative aspects will give Australian families and the long-term unemployed a number of things to be apprehensive about. This bill is an assault on the principles on which the social security system is based and also on many of the values that underpin the Australian conception of a fair and just society. If the government is not prepared to take out the negative aspects, they should allow the bill to be split. In this way, the House can allow the positive aspects to go through speedily and then allow us to debate the negative aspects of the bill.
Earlier this year, the Australians working together bill was referred to the Senate Community Affairs References Committee with terms of reference that allowed the committee to consider the findings of the Independent Review of Breaches and Penalties in the Social Security System. This is known as the Pearce report. The report recommends a series of legislative and administrative changes to the breaching provisions of the Social Security Act, which the Howard government now largely ignores.
In particular, the report made a series of recommendations aimed at improving the effectiveness and fairness of the social security system, with particular attention to the implementation of breaches. In my experience as a community worker and now as the federal member for Stirling, I have first-hand experience of the effects that rigid and harsh breaching penalties can have on the unemployed and their families. They often cause unnecessary and unjustifiable hardship, which only further impedes the unemployed in their search for employment. Breaching means loss of income to a person or family. This loss of income is a barrier to the person or family in their efforts to find a job. As we all know, job hunting is expensive; taking away income increases a person's prospects of remaining unemployed for a longer period or keeps them trapped in poverty for a longer period.
Although this bill does contain a number of positive steps which will assist people back to paid employment, the AWT bill pays only lip-service to some of the deeper sources of injustice which are prevalent in our social security system. The Howard government's move to introduce the concept of mutual obligation does not recognise the personal pressures and differing circumstances of unemployed people in contemporary Australia. The Howard government fails to give equal concern to these members of the community and therefore fails to give them a fair go at attaining gainful employment. While the Howard government preaches the notion of obligation to Australians, it is itself neglecting to meet its obligations to certain unemployed citizens. This point was picked up by the Pearce report, which states that, although the system often functions in an appropriate manner, there are many occasions on which it can be `reasonably described as arbitrary, unfair or excessively harsh'. 
A central issue is whether parents who are receiving income support and whose youngest children are between 13 and 15 years of age should be obligated to undertake certain activities as a condition of payment. The Howard government fails to see the reality of raising a family in today's world. It is becoming increasingly harder to balance family responsibilities with the economic necessities of modern life. It was a Labor government in 1991 that established Jobs, Education and Training—the JET scheme—for people receiving parenting payments. Labor recognised the difficulties for single parents in balancing work and family responsibilities and the need to ensure that single parents without skills or work experience were not suddenly shunted onto an activity tested payment when their youngest child turned 16. However, the Howard government has reversed the focus of public policy, deciding that we should pander to corporate Australia rather than try to give ordinary Australians a fair go.
There are a lot of urban myths out there in the Australian community about sole parents. In fact, there is a belief that sole parents are a drain on the taxpayer because they are receiving social security benefits. To deal with this urban myth and to ensure that the House understands the characteristics and life patterns of sole parents, I asked the Parliamentary Library to obtain some facts and figures for me to use in this debate. The Parliamentary Library was very helpful, and the information I would have mentioned if I had time comes from the government. In fact, it comes from a media release of the Minister for Family and Community Services, Senator Amanda Vanstone, called `Sole Parents deserve praise and support', dated 5 April 2002, as well as from the Department of Family and Community Services annual reports for 2000-01 and 2001-02. 
I fail to see the justice in forcing some of the most vulnerable sections of society to undertake certain activities—with the threat of losing their means of subsistence if they fail to comply—especially given the force of the reasons for noncompliance. The shadow minister has covered the issue very well, so we can move on and proceed to other equally pressing legislation.
The Howard government needs to take a good, hard look at its values. The government seems more intent than ever before to pander to the top end of town and ensure that executive salaries continue to escalate while the people at the other end of the spectrum pay the price. The Howard government can start this process. Firstly, it can amend the AWT bill to ensure wider exemptions, improved safeguards and greater flexibility in the proposed participation arrangements for parents and mature age unemployed. Secondly, it can give effect to the majority of the legislative reforms proposed in the Pearce report. If it does not, I will have no choice but to ask the government to split the bill. I will support the $900 million of positive measures; I will oppose the negative measures. Thank you.

name: Anthony, Larry, MP
text:
—I thank the previous speaker, the member for Stirling, and the member for Lilley for their contributions to the debate on the Family and Community Services Legislation Amendment (Australians Working Together and other 2001 Budget Measures) Bill 2002. However, a couple of points need to be raised. There is an indication here that the government is setting this up to fail. That is not the case at all. Indeed, Senator Vanstone acted in good faith in negotiating with the ALP.
—Pass it.
—The ALP very conveniently want to split the bill, as they have tried to do with previous bills we have dealt with when there is a savings measure or other positive measure. It is absolute hypocrisy by the member for Lilley. His display in the House of Representatives this afternoon was perhaps a justification of the embarrassing situation when he refused to rule out his leadership credentials last week in the middle of this AWT debate. Even on AM and a number of other programs, he was hedging his bets: `Maybe we will; maybe we won't.' All we can hear now is: `Pass the bill.' That is exactly it. We do want to pass the whole bill. That is exactly right. But no, the Labor Party, just as they have done with the PBS and other measures, want to cherry pick. 
The fact is that it is this government which has actually embarked on welfare reform to ensure that people are given much better opportunities. It is interesting that the member for Lilley raised the issue of breaching. Under the Labor Party—particularly when he was last on this side of the House—if you had a breach it was `one strike and you're out'. That was the Labor Party's policy on breaching. How fair was that? Swan by name, goose by nature. Their breaching regime was one strike and you're out—you lost your total payment. That was the ALP's compassion when it came to welfare reform. 
When we introduced the breaching policy, guess who supported it? The Australian Labor Party. I remember the words of Senator Faulkner in the Senate. He said, `These are good measures.' They were even supported by ACOSS. But they do not quite like this, because they see that they can have a political advantage. Many of these changes that we made were made before the Pearce report, in recognition of those vulnerable job seekers. It is interesting to note the `facts' that the member for Lilley throws around, sprouting misinformation. He said that 43 per cent of breach decisions have been overturned on appeal. That is totally incorrect; it was 1.2 per cent in the last financial year. The fact is that the breaching rate has gone down by about 33 per cent since we introduced more compassionate measures—particularly for those who are vulnerable. By the same token, we have a firm policy of deterrence, which is absolutely necessary when it comes to ensuring that people fulfil their job seeking and mutual obligation requirements.
It was also interesting when he talked about what we were allegedly trying to do with DSP. We actually adopted all the funding measures; and of course the more important measure of trying to focus people with disabilities back onto their abilities was rejected by the Australian Labor Party. They talk about vulnerable job seekers and those on the disability support pension, but in 1991 the Keating government made the decision to change the classification and park a huge number of Australians on DSP by artificially deflating unemployment figures. That is why today we have more than 650,000—and climbing—people on DSP. That is not fair, because the measure that we tried to put in place under the original DSP bill not only ensured extra funding for employment and disability services but also focused on people's abilities rather than letting them languish. That is politically convenient for the Labor Party when it comes to people who are vulnerable.
In many ways, the AWT bill that we have tried to put up in its entirety reintroduces a more flexible and relevant working credit to overcome those lumps in payments for people who are going in and out of the work force or who are having difficulty in gaining employment. There is extra funding, particularly in literacy, numeracy and other programs. But the greatest crisis that we have now, particularly with a lot of lone parents, is that 850,000 children are growing up in jobless families. Fifty per cent of lone parents will remain on benefits five years after the youngest child has turned 16. Why shouldn't we encourage those parents to come back in to Centrelink—
—You never did it! Interestingly, under the Australian Labor Party there were one million people unemployed. That is your welfare policy: park more people on DSP and give fewer opportunities, particularly to sole parents and young families. What we are doing, quite deliberately, is trying prevention and intervention with sole parents when they call into Centrelink. When their child goes into primary school, we expect certain requirements to be met including at least six hours of some type of voluntary contribution as part of the mutual obligation. I think we have been extremely fair and quite transparent, from the McClure report through all the changes that we have been trying to make with welfare reform—
—Name one!
—I will name the one person who has been the champion opposer, and that is the member for Lilley. We know that the member for Lilley—he gets the big tick—is more interested in his future political ambitions here at the front desk. I am sure the member for Brand might be able to give him a few tips. During his diatribe he talked about the highest taxing government. As far as GDP is concerned, the highest taxing government was the Australian Labor Party when they were last in government. All these measures that we are planning with AWT are about improving the ultimate long-term financial viability and employment prospects, particularly for lone parents, and also ensuring that, for parents and mature-aged individuals receiving Newstart or other types of social security payments, there is some type of compliance but also some type of reward.  
This is political opportunism by the Labor Party. They were meant to be acting in good faith; of course, they are going to try to reject it now. This is just their typical fashion: they are trying to cherry pick legislation and play to their very limited constituency. This bill should be supported in its entirety. I hope that there might be a conversion on the road to Damascus rather than on the road to the leadership, which is clearly what the member for Lilley had in mind in dropping the ball, particularly when negotiations were taking place—I see that smirk of his now—a couple of weeks ago. We believe that it is important to have the whole bill passed and to ensure that all Australians, particularly parents and mature aged workers—with issues like working credit and all our other spending measures—get the best possible chance. This is all about this government providing more long-term welfare reform and ultimately seeing more people focused on their ability and getting gainful employment. I support the bill in its entirety.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I am delighted we have extracted that confession—
 (Hon. D.G.H. Adams)—Order! The minister has closed the debate. 
—What has he done?
—The honourable member for Lilley will resume his seat. 
Question put:
That the motion (Mr Anthony's) be agreed to.

name: Smith, Stephen, MP
text:
—The opposition supports this package of bills in respect of medical indemnity insurance, but in the course of my remarks I will move a second reading amendment drawing attention to the government's shortcomings and failings in this area.
On 23 October this year, the government announced a package of measures to address rising medical indemnity insurance premiums and to ensure a viable and ongoing medical indemnity insurance market. In particular, the government announced an extension of the existing guarantee to United Medical Protection and Australasian Medical Insurance Ltd, UMP-AMIL, to 31 December 2003; partial subsidies for insurance premiums for obstetricians, neurosurgeons and GPs performing procedures; a scheme to meet 50 per cent of the cost of claim payments greater than $2 million, up to the insured amount, made by medical indemnity insurers; funding of the incurred but not reported—IBNR—liabilities for those medical defence organisations—MDOs—that have not set aside money to cover these liabilities; a levy to recoup the cost of the funding for IBNR liabilities for members of the relevant MDOs over an extended period; MDOs are to be brought into a new regulatory framework administered by the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority; and the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission is to monitor medical indemnity insurance premiums to determine whether they are actuarially and commercially justified.
The announcement of these measures followed the passage of the Medical Indemnity Agreement (Financial Assistance—Binding Commonwealth Obligations) Bill 2002. The purpose of that bill was to appropriate funds for payments in accordance with an indemnity agreement between the Commonwealth and UMP and its wholly owned subsidiary, AMIL, and to confirm the government's commitments relating to UMP-AMIL. As I have indicated, part of the government's announcement on 23 October was to extend that guarantee to 31 December 2003.
The package of bills that the House is debating gives effect to those elements of the government's policy announced on 23 October. There are three main measures that the bills give effect to. The first measure is the IBNR scheme. The IBNR scheme assists those MDOs which had unfunded IBNRs as at 30 June 2002 to pay for those claims when they crystallise. In other words, the Commonwealth will help these MDOs to pay for claims which they have not adequately provisioned in the past. The IBNR scheme consists of two parts: firstly, the Commonwealth providing funding for medical defence organisations' IBNR liabilities that were unfunded as at 30 June 2002, with payouts beginning in early 2003; and, secondly, recouping the cost of funding those liabilities through a levy on members of the medical defence organisations with unfunded IBNRs. Members of those MDOs whose IBNRs were fully funded as at 30 June 2002 will not pay the levy. The package of bills provides for the Commonwealth making these payments and recouping the cost from doctors who are members of the affected medical defence organisations.
The IBNR levy will be payable by any person who on 30 June 2000 was a member of an MDO that was assessed as having unfunded IBNR liabilities as at 30 June 2002. The levy will be tax deductible. Exemptions from the levy will apply to the estates of deceased members, members who have retired before 31 December 2001 and student members as at 30 June 2000. Medical practitioners who belong to an MDO that is fully provisioned for its IBNRs will not be subject to the levy. For those practitioners who are liable to pay the levy, it will be set as a proportion—a maximum of 50 per cent—of their medical indemnity premium paid for the 2000-01 financial year.
The second key measure which the package of bills gives effect to is the high-cost claims scheme. The high-cost claims scheme addresses the issue of high cost claims and relates to medical incidents in this package of bills. It aims to lower premiums by reducing the potential cost of large claims to insurers. Under this scheme, the Commonwealth will meet 50 per cent of the cost of claim payments greater than $2 million up to the insured amount made by medical indemnity insurers. This scheme will apply to claims notified on or after 1 January 2003. It will not apply to claims relating to the provision of public hospital services.
The third main measure which the package of bills gives effect to is subsidies. A subsidy will be provided to obstetricians, neurosurgeons and procedural GPs who undertake Medicare billable procedures. It will be the equivalent of 50 per cent of the difference between the cost of their premiums plus the IBNR levy, if applicable, and a corresponding cost for gynaecologists, general surgeons and nonprocedural GPs respectively in their relevant state or territory. In light of the particularly high premium costs faced by some neurosurgeons, combined with their relatively limited scope to derive income from private practice, the subsidy rate will increase to 80 per cent on the portion of their premium plus the levy, if applicable, that exceeds $50,000. Accessing the subsidy will be conditional on medical practitioners participating in quality and safety programs designed to protect patients and minimise the incidence of injuries. The subsidy will apply to the premium paid net of GST, as GST on the premium is eligible for an input tax credit, together with state and territory stamp duties. 
The package of bills provides for the implementation of those key measures in the following way: firstly, the Medical Indemnity Bill 2002 provides for determining which medical defence organisations, MDOs, have unfunded, incurred but not reported liabilities. The bill also provides for the Commonwealth making payments in relation to claims forming part of the unfunded IBNR liability of MDOs as at 30 June 2002 and in relation to high-cost claims and subsidies for certain medical practitioners; Commonwealth payments in relation to part of the cost of large claims against MDOs or medical indemnity insurers in relation to incidents notified after 1 January 2002; subsidies to assist medical practitioners in meeting the cost of indemnity coverage; and an administration mechanism to support levies on doctors to pay for the IBNR scheme and the enhanced UMP guarantee.
The Medical Indemnity (IBNR Indemnity) Contribution Bill 2002 imposes the levy for the IBNR scheme on doctors in those MDOs with unfunded liabilities. The Medical Indemnity (Enhanced UMP Indemnity) Contribution Bill 2002 imposes a levy on UMP members to cover the cost of the Commonwealth of any part under the deed of indemnity, be it with the Commonwealth, UMP-AMIL and the provisional liquidator of UMP-AMIL.
The Medical Indemnity (Consequential Amendments) Bill 2002 provides for amendments to the acts as a result of the medical indemnity bills. My understanding is that a number of medical defence organisations have been in discussion with the government in relation to some of the technical aspects of the bill. This may result in the need for technical amendment to the bill and, provided those technical amendments are consistent with the thrust of the bill, they will be supported by the opposition both here and in the other place. I note that the government has given notice of a number of technical amendments which have recently been circulated. I have not yet had the opportunity of considering those in detail but I may have that opportunity over the dinner break. In any event, they can be considered by the Senate.
I also understand that consideration is being given by the Senate to referring these bills to the relevant Senate legislation committee for a short report. I would hope that any such referral by the Senate to a committee would not delay the passage of these pieces of legislation, package of measures, prior to the parliament getting up for the Christmas break. My understanding also is that to facilitate that it is the view of the opposition that the relevant cut-off exemption should be granted by the Senate for the consideration of these bills.
So far as financial implications are concerned, the Mid-Year Economic and Fiscal Outlook documents, MYEFO documents, provide for funding of $246.5 million over four years for the medical indemnity insurance assistance package in the following way: $54.4 million in 2002-03; $64.4 million in 2003-04; $63.7 million in 2004-05; and $63.5 million in 2005-06. The MYEFO documents do not disclose the amount budgeted for the UMP-AMIL guarantee or the expected amount to be raised from the IBNR levy to fund the guarantee.
As I indicated at the outset of my remarks, the opposition supports these measures. That is not to say that the conduct of the government in this matter has been exemplary; on the contrary, it is subject to great criticism both in the medical profession and on our side. As a consequence, I foreshadow that, before the conclusion of my remarks, I will formally move the following amendment, which I am happy to have circulated: 
That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
“while supporting the passage of the Bills, the House:
(1)	condemns the Government for not adequately recognising the medical indemnity insurance problem and not acting quickly enough to address its adverse effects, including higher medical costs and reduced availability of services for Australians and their families; and
(2)	condemns the Government for failing to address the effects of higher medical indemnity insurance premiums on midwives, private hospitals, family planning clinics and aboriginal medical services; and
(3)	calls on the Government to:
(a)	assume a leadership role in the co-ordination of reforms necessary to State and Territory laws with the aim of uniformity in tort law reforms;
(b)	consider putting in place a national scheme to ensure the long term care and rehabilitation needs of catastrophically injured Australians;
(c)	ask the ACCC to ensure that whatever changes occur in medical indemnity insurance, no unfair or unreasonable oncosts flow to patients for the cost of their health care;
(d)	play a more active role in bringing together medical defence organisations and representing them in negotiations with reinsurers; and
(e)	support APRA with appropriate resources to fulfil its greater regulatory role in medical indemnity insurance”.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 p.m. to 8.00 p.m.
—Before the break I flagged a second reading amendment to draw attention to the failure of the Howard government to properly address medical indemnity insurance problems. Whilst the crisis in medical indemnity insurance was publicly brought to a head by the financial difficulties experienced by UMP and by the appointment of a provisional liquidator, problems with medical indemnity insurance are not of recent origin. For example, in 1991 the previous Labor government established a review of professional indemnity arrangements for health care professionals. This review was chaired by Fiona Tito and it was responsible for examining the arrangements relating to professional indemnity and the experience with compensation for medical misadventure. 
Fiona Tito's report was completed at the end of 1995 and was released in January 1996. That report, amongst other things, recognised the importance of effective and ethical communication between health care professionals and patients; identified the need to develop evidence based medicine and define best practice, using tools such as clinical practice guidelines; called on health care institutions to develop a system for error identification and analysis to deal with errors in a positive manner; identified the tendency for doctors to practise medical defence medicine; discussed the need to ensure that people with severe disabilities obtained early access to rehabilitation services; recommended the wider use of structured settlements; recommended that medical defence organisations, using common accounting and reporting standards, ensure that members and policyholders be able to assess their relative financial strength; recommended that products be offered in a fair and accurate way; and recommended the establishment of an MDO fund to cover the costs of claims incurred but not reported, the famous IBNR, by a specified date. 
The Tito report, unfortunately, was largely ignored by the current government and its recommendations were not acted upon. In the run-up to the last federal election in November 2001, Labor recognised the need for action in the area of medical indemnity insurance and identified areas needing reform. Labor's medical indemnity reform package had been announced in July 2001 and it drew attention to the following requirements: the need to reduce the frequency of medical injuries by setting national benchmarks and guidelines and by promoting the use of information technologies to help doctors decide on the best treatment and avoid misdiagnosis or incorrect treatment; the need to promote structured settlements by changing the tax treatment of periodic payments to ensure injured patients have adequate regular payments to cover their health care costs for the rest of their lives; and the need to establish a national database on health care litigation to target the problem areas and to ensure that adequate support mechanisms are in place.  
The package sought: consistent state and territory reforms to legislation covering court procedures, the calculation of damages and the regulation of medical indemnity organisations; to tighten the prudential regulation of medical indemnity insurance to ensure that all funds operate soundly and have transparent accounts; to remove the open discretion held by some medical defence mutuals to decline coverage; to require all doctors to hold the appropriate insurance for the work they undertook; to reduce red tape by harmonising requirements from doctor registration; to improve risk management by medical indemnity funds, including working with the royal colleges to reduce the rate of medical injuries and to provide incentives for quality practice; and to refer the current problems with indemnity insurance for midwives to the then Senate inquiry into nursing to look at options to ensure that homebirths remained an option for expectant mothers. 
The Howard government regrettably was reluctant to play a role in addressing medical indemnity insurance and only took its preliminary steps following the last federal election. In December 2001, the Prime Minister belatedly announced a national medical indemnity insurance summit, which was ultimately convened on 23 April 2002. The summit's communique, which was issued following the summit on 23 April, frankly did no more than to announce that work would begin on a range of issues that had been identified as early as the Tito report and certainly as early as Labor's medical indemnity insurance package, which was released in July 2001. 
It is undeniably the case that the problems surrounding medical indemnity insurance are complex and there is no single solution. As a consequence, action is required by federal, state and territory governments and change is required of medical defence organisations, the medical profession and lawyers. Any comprehensive plan for solving the medical indemnity insurance problem must be coordinated at the Commonwealth level and it requires cooperation and agreement with each of the states and territories on necessary reforms in jurisdictions to complement such a national approach. Labor has repeatedly called on the Howard government to assume a leadership role in the coordination of reforms necessary to state and territory tort law and has highlighted the desirability of achieving uniformity in tort law reforms. Labor has also called on the Howard government to act in those areas for which it has responsibility, including dealing with issues of quality and safety of medical care, the establishment of a scheme for the care of catastrophically injured Australians, a heightened role for the ACCC to ensure that patients do not unreasonably bear the increased costs of medical indemnity insurance.
The second reading amendment which I flagged draws attention to Labor's proposal for further Howard government action in this area. Firstly, there are areas that have been badly neglected, in my view, by focusing almost all of the efforts for reform on tort law and by not focusing more attention on the need to improve clinical outcomes and reduce clinical risk. Certainly it is the case that much of the debate about medical indemnity insurance has focused on the need for tort law reform. At the same time, regrettably, comparatively little attention has been given to reducing the number of adverse events through the encouragement of safer medical practice. Improvements in the quality and safety of medical care would lead to better health outcomes for patients and reduce the likelihood that doctors would be sued for inappropriate treatment. Whilst it is certainly the case that Australia performs well internationally, we can always do better. As a consequence, the Howard government should, in my view, make improving clinical outcomes and reducing clinical risk a much greater priority insofar as long-term improvement to this area is concerned.
Secondly, more work needs to be done in considering whether a national scheme for the long-term care of the most catastrophically injured could be established. Labor has consistently advocated that a special national scheme is necessary to address high-cost cases in which catastrophic injury has resulted from medical procedures. It is clearly the case, both anecdotally and statistically, that the majority of these cases involve brain and spinal injuries and obstetrics. Complex cases involving catastrophically injured people take years to resolve through the courts and waste thousands, if not millions, of dollars in legal fees. These cases place a disproportionate burden on the cost of medical indemnity insurance. Putting in place a catastrophic injury scheme would be a significant contribution to stemming the exponential increase in premiums for the cost of medical indemnity insurance. 
The Commonwealth also has a significant role to play in assisting medical defence organisations to secure reasonably priced reinsurance. Australia has a multiplicity of generally state based organisations that provide medical indemnity insurance. With a more united front, Australian medical defence organisations would be much more likely to succeed in obtaining affordable reinsurance and helping to keep the cost of medical indemnity insurance from exponentially increasing. It is certainly the case these days that, to obtain medical indemnity reinsurance, one has to fly to London, Brussels or Geneva, and the Commonwealth playing a representative role in that capacity would certainly be of assistance to the various medical defence organisations.
Changing the way in which medical indemnity insurance is regulated would also be a helpful advance. Medical indemnity insurance has historically been provided by a small number of state based medical defence organisations which have traditionally offered doctors membership rather than insurance. For this reason, regulation by the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority has, until recently, been poor. APRA recently moved to increase its regulation of the MDOs, including by requiring MDOs to cease discretionary cover and requiring insurance contracts, and obtaining undertakings from MDOs that have the effect of bringing them under direct APRA regulation. It is important that the Commonwealth ensure that APRA has the appropriate resources to fulfil this greater regulatory role.
The Commonwealth should also ensure the prevention of price exploitation as a result of premium increases, and this envisages an increased role for the ACCC. It is now well known that very many patients are being asked to make large up-front payments by their specialists before surgical procedures are carried out, with the explicit justification that these up-front fees are necessary to defray the increased costs of medical indemnity insurance. We have also seen in more recent times indications from the Australian Private Hospitals Association that, in the course of next year, up-front fees in the order of $150 will be imposed to cover the difficulties that Australian private hospitals now find in gaining medical indemnity insurance.
While it is expected that medical service providers will not be able to absorb the increased costs of medical indemnity insurance premiums and will, in many instances, seek to pass these costs on to patients, at a minimum, consumers should not be required to pay amounts which bear no relation to the increased premium costs. Whilst the ACCC only has jurisdiction with respect to medical services which are provided by incorporated bodies and not over doctors who practise as individuals or in partnerships, there is a definite role the ACCC can play in protecting consumers. Although the Howard government's decision envisages the ACCC playing a role so far as monitoring the increase in medical indemnity insurance premiums is concerned, there is also a role for the ACCC in ensuring that, whatever changes occur in medical indemnity insurance, no unfair or unreasonable costs flow on to patients for the cost of their individual health care.
Those concerns are expressed in the second reading amendment which I detailed to the House prior to the break and has been circulated in my name. I also indicated that, in the course of the dinner break, I might have the opportunity of looking at the amendments which have been circulated by the government and going through the supplementary explanatory memorandum.
 Whilst, of course, over that short period of time I would not regard this as a definitive analysis, there appears to be nothing in the proposed amendments by the government, as reflected by the explanatory memorandum and the amendments as circulated, which does anything other than pursue the substantive objectives of the bill and make technical amendments to facilitate that effect. So we support the passage of the legislation and indicate preliminary support for the technical amendments as circulated by the government. My amendment draws attention to the government's failure to anticipate the problems which would arise in medical indemnity insurance. I move:  
That all words after “That” be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
“while supporting the passage of the Bills, the House:
(1)	condemns the Government for not adequately recognising the medical indemnity insurance problem and not acting quickly enough to address its adverse effects, including higher medical costs and reduced availability of services for Australians and their families; and
(2)	condemns the Government for failing to address the effects of higher medical indemnity insurance premiums on midwives, private hospitals, family planning clinics and aboriginal medical services; and
(3)	calls on the Government to:
(a)	assume a leadership role in the co-ordination of reforms necessary to State and Territory laws with the aim of uniformity in tort law reforms;
(b)	consider putting in place a national scheme to ensure the long term care and rehabilitation needs of catastrophically injured Australians;
(c)	ask the ACCC to ensure that whatever changes occur in medical indemnity insurance, no unfair or unreasonable oncosts flow to patients for the cost of their health care;
(d)	play a more active role in bringing together medical defence organisations and representing them in negotiations with reinsurers; and
(e)	support APRA with appropriate resources to fulfil its greater regulatory role in medical indemnity insurance”.
 (Hon. L.R.S. Price)—Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment.

name: Southcott, Dr Andrew, MP
text:
—Even prior to the collapse of HIH and the terrorist attack on the World Trade Centre, it was evident that there were problems in the field of general insurance. Within Australia, FAI and HIH had priced their premiums unrealistically without regard to risk and, in addition, there had been a worldwide problem in reinsurance. All of these factors contributed in some way to the problems in medical indemnity insurance, which was demonstrated dramatically this year by the collapse of UMP. 
Medical indemnity is provided by the medical defence organisations. In Australia these include UMP, the Medical Defence Association of Australia, Medical Indemnity Protection Society, MDASA, MDAWA, the Medical Protection Society of Tasmania and the Queensland Doctors Mutual Ltd. It is important to understand that they are not insurers; they are not-for-profit mutuals. They do not issue insurance contracts; they protect their members in return for subscription income, and they rely on reinsurance to do this. Since 1999, four of the main MDOs have had to make a call on their members for additional funds.
I will outline some of the recent events that have occurred this year. On 3 May 2002 a provisional liquidator was appointed to UMP and its subsidiary. UMP covers 60 per cent of doctors in Australia for professional indemnity cover. We have seen subscriptions to MDOs increase dramatically. We have also seen that the MDOs have not provided for their incurred but not reported claims. In response to the collapse of UMP, on 31 May the government announced that it would assist UMP to cover payment for claims finalised and incidents between 29 April and 30 June. This was then extended to 31 December 2002.
On 23 October 2002 there was a joint announcement by the Prime Minister, the Minister for Health and Ageing and also the Assistant Treasurer that: firstly, the guarantee would be extended to 31 December 2003; secondly, there would be government funding for the incurred but not reported liability at 30 June 2002 where the IBNRs are unfunded; thirdly, there would be government reimbursement for medical indemnity providers, either MDOs or medical indemnity insurers, on a per claim basis for 50 per cent of the insurance payouts over $2 million for incidents notified on or after 1 January 2003—this is the high-cost claim section; fourthly, there would be provision of premium subsidies for obstetricians, neurosurgeons and procedural GPs—this measure is conditional on these practitioners attending incident management and quality assurance programs; fifthly, there would be a cost recovery which would consist of a levy on members for the unfunded incurred but not reported liabilities and payments would be made by members of the MDOs to the Commonwealth to cover the cost to the Commonwealth of payments in relation to those unfunded IBNR liabilities; and lastly, medical indemnity insurance providers would have prudential supervision from APRA and would act more commercially in future. Changes in accounting standards will require the MDOs to include IBNRs on their balance sheets and provision for them. 
This legislation comprises four bills which implement the measures which were announced on 23 October 2002, except for the prudential supervision by APRA. I welcome the announcement of 23 October as a good, commonsense outcome and a good approach to the vexed question of professional indemnity insurance and medical indemnity insurance in this case.
The Medical Indemnity (IBNR Indemnity) Contribution Bill 2002 and the Medical Indemnity (Enhanced UMP Indemnity) Contribution Bill 2002 are both taxation bills. To satisfy section 55 of the Constitution, which states that laws imposing taxation shall only deal with the imposition of taxation and any provision therein dealing with any other matter shall be of no effect, they are separate bills. But the main bill is the Medical Indemnity Bill 2002, which is under debate at the moment along with the other ones.
I will now refer to the IBNR indemnity scheme. Where MDOs have not provided for the incurred but not reported liabilities, the Commonwealth will meet the liabilities as they fall due but they will also levy doctors to cover the cost. This will allow the MDOs to continue without being burdened by past IBNRs. It allows in essence a fresh start. Division 1 of part 2 of this bill provides that, if MDOs do not have enough money to fund their IBNRs, the Commonwealth will pay money to the MDOs providing that the MDOs are participating MDOs. Whether they are participating MDOs is subject to ministerial discretion. If, for example, an MDO does have sufficient funds to pay their IBNR then the minister can determine that the fund is non-participating. This covers incidents occurring before 30 June 2002 but notified after 30 June 2002. The MDO will make the payment and will then be reimbursed by the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth may pay all or a percentage of the claim. This is covered in clauses 21 to 23 of this bill. The proportion of the payment will be assessed by the Australian Government Actuary to reflect the proportion of the participating MDO's IBNR liabilities which are unfunded. There is an important exception to this: IBNR payments will not be made for an incident relating to a public patient in a public hospital. I presume that is because the coverage is provided by the state governments in that case.
I turn to the part of the bill which relates to high-cost claims. The Commonwealth's partial coverage of high-cost claims will improve the affordability of premiums, it will improve the bottom line of the medical defence organisations, and it may even encourage new entrants to come into the market—which at the moment, without these changes, is not an attractive market to be in.
Clauses 29 and 30 in division 2 of the bill provide that the Commonwealth will pay 50 per cent of insurance payments over $2 million. The 50 per cent figure can be changed by regulation. This will apply to a claim in Australia which is notified after 1 January 2003 and is greater than $2 million or an amount which can be changed by regulation and where the medical defence organisation has paid the amount or is liable to pay. Once again, there is an exception for incidents involving public patients in public hospitals and I assume that is for the reason that their liability is covered by the state governments. 
Clause 43 of the bill, dealing with the medical indemnity subsidy scheme, states that the minister can determine medical practitioners who will receive a subsidy for the medical indemnity premiums. On 23 October, the Prime Minister stated that this would apply to obstetricians, neurosurgeons and GP proceduralists, and there are good reasons why those professional groups are included. This measure will help to make premiums more affordable for these groups. These groups have major affordability issues relative to their incomes and relative to their professional peers in the specialties for obstetricians and neurosurgeons, but also for GP proceduralists.
The subsidy will be 50 per cent of the difference between the premium and the incurred but not reported levy for the obstetricians, neurosurgeons and procedural GPs, relative to those of gynaecologists, general surgeons and non-procedural GPs. So we will be looking at the difference between the risk premiums of an obstetrician and a gynaecologist, a neurosurgeon and a general surgeon, and a procedural GP and a non-procedural GP. Obstetricians and neurosurgeons are high-risk subspecialties and are associated with high premiums. They are not high income for a specialist group, and they spend up to one-third of their Medicare income on premiums. Neurosurgeons pay high premiums and have limited capacity to earn income from private practice, and so another section of the Medical Indemnity Bill 2002 provides that the subsidy will be 80 per cent for the premium plus the levy where it is over $50,000. Obstetricians, neurosurgeons and orthopaedic surgeons are often included in the three specialties that pay the highest premiums, but orthopaedic surgeons are not included here. An examination of their premiums showed that around the states their premiums are much lower than those of obstetricians and neurosurgeons: approximately $25,000 in 2001-02.
I move to procedural GPs. In general, this group most commonly practises in rural and remote areas and has a low volume of procedural services, so it is difficult to recoup the cost of the medical indemnity for services such as obstetrics. But they provide a very important service, and without having this sort of cover we would lose the procedures these general practitioners are able to perform in rural and remote areas.
Part 3 of the bill deals with financing the schemes. Division 1 sets out that all members of a participating MDO as at 30 June 2000 are required to make a contribution unless they have died, retired before 31 December 2000, were a student at 30 June 2000 or have alternative insurance. The rate is based on the indemnity premium or subscription paid by the members. This will only apply to doctors who belong to an MDO with an unfunded incurred but not reported liability as at 30 June 2002. Doctors who are members of an MDO that has funded its IBNR liabilities will not need to pay a levy. Paying the levy is a more affordable option for the medical profession than the past method, which was the MDO making a call on its members or introducing higher premiums. We saw that several times with UMP. The levy can be paid in a lump sum or by instalments, or it can be deferred for a year—for example, if the members take time out of the work force or go overseas. The levy is expected to run for five years to make it affordable. The annual amount will be limited to 50 per cent of a doctor's 2000-01 premium, and the levy is also tax-deductible.
Division 2 of part 3 of the bill sets out that members of the UMP as at 1 July 2002 must pay a contribution to cover the cost of the Commonwealth guarantee to the provisional liquidator of UMP, AMIL, covering 1 July 2002 to 31 December 2003. With regard to the UMP indemnity contributions, UMP members are required to pay the levy if UMP goes into liquidation, under the deed of indemnity between the Commonwealth, UMP and the provisional liquidators. I turn to the financial impact of the bill. It is estimated that the annual cost of high-cost claims is $19 million to $35 million, although this depends on the progress and nature of state tort law reform. The other impacts have already been included in the 2001-02 budget impact.
The Royal Australasian College of Surgeons has proposed a single medical defence organisation. There is nothing to stop any of the seven existing MDOs merging with another; that is really a matter for them. It is of course also subject to the Trade Practices Act and the ACCC. However, size is not everything; UMP shows us that. They had a 60 per cent market share but still were not able to price their premiums properly. 
This bill provides an important response to the collapse of UMP and also to the difficulties medical defence organisations have. There are also some long-term measures, which the opposition spokesman on health spoke about and which are being addressed by the government. First of all, tort law reform is the subject of negotiations with the states. We are already starting to see some cases in the state court systems overturning previous cases in terms of medical negligence and the definitions thereof. Also, long-term care costs will be helped by the high-cost claims scheme. That scheme covers high-cost claims greater than $2 million. It is important to make the point that the number of catastrophically injured as a result of medical negligence is very small compared with the whole population. Motor vehicle accidents, for example, are much more common. This is an area of direct responsibility for the states. They have the infrastructure in place to assist people with catastrophic injuries. So it is up to the states to explore the feasibility of allowing a victim of medical negligence access to the services provided under these schemes. We want to see access to services rather than a new bureaucracy. While I sympathise with those who have family or friends who have been catastrophically injured, there is, as I said, existing infrastructure in the states.
I turn to the issue of clinical risk management. Any doctor receiving a subsidy—and that includes that group of obstetricians, neurosurgeons and GP proceduralists—must do quality and service safety activities as a result of the Commonwealth assistance. There are other initiatives of the government which are operating on a much wider systemic scale—for example, the Australian Council for Safety and Quality in Health Care, chaired by Bruce Barraclough, which is promoting improvement in safety issues. They divide it into priority areas: one, supporting those who work in the health system; two, improving data and information for safer health care; three, involving consumers in improving health care safety; four, redesigning systems to facilitate a culture of safety; and, five, building awareness and understanding of health care safety.
