Some of the practical things the council are focusing on are, firstly, reducing patient harm associated with medication use; secondly, reducing patient harm resulting from health care associated infections; thirdly, coordinating national action to learn from serious events; and, lastly, developing national standards to support more open disclosure to patients and their carers.
Last of all, the high-cost claims scheme will help to reduce reinsurance costs. This could encourage new entrants. By improving the market conditions, our medical defence organisations would be in a good position to negotiate their reinsurance contracts because of the high-cost claims scheme. We think it is more important for us to make this a more attractive market than to negotiate on behalf of the MDOs. Our expertise is not in insurance. We are not in the insurance business. This legislation has been introduced in response to a crisis in medical indemnity, but we believe it is more important to improve market conditions than to represent the MDOs in the reinsurance treaties. We are not in the insurance business.

name: Hall, Jill, MP
text:
—Whilst the opposition is not opposing the Medical Indemnity Bill 2002 and related bills, I would like to place on the record my absolute disgust at the government's handling of this matter. Its handling of the medical indemnity insurance crisis has left a lot to be desired. In doing so, I would like to support the amendments moved by the member for Perth. I have to condemn the government for the way it has vacillated, procrastinated and delayed bringing in this legislation. In doing that, I would like to put on record that it is not only members of the opposition and the constituents we speak to on a day-to-day basis but also the doctors who have been relying on the government to resolve this matter and to resolve it a lot quicker than it has done. Doctors have been very concerned about the delay in coming up with any viable, long-term solution to this problem. 
The government's action in this area has really left a lot to be desired. As well as creating uncertainty for the medical profession, it has created uncertainty for mums, dads and their children in my electorate and electorates throughout Australia. When the crisis first eventuated, various doctors closed their doors because they were so uncertain as to the future, and it left a great void. Here we are six months later and we finally have legislation. It is not the full answer to the problem, but we are a little bit further down the track than we were before the government announced these measures. They are a starting point. The states and territories moved a lot quicker than the federal government did. In New South Wales, the health minister announced that all doctors working in the public system would be covered, and there have been moves to change the tort laws in the states. Unfortunately, I must compare this to the response of the federal government, which vacillated and delayed making a decision. That is something we have come to expect from this government, unless it is about introducing legislation that is going to benefit its friends.
Finally, after much delay, the government did come up with the legislation we are debating today. As I have mentioned, this delay jeopardised patient care and the delivery of health services and created this uncertainty and other things I will mention as I continue. This has been symbolic of the government's performance in the area of health. On 23 October, the government announced a package of measures to address the rising medical indemnity insurance premiums and to ensure viable, ongoing medical indemnity coverage. In particular, the government announced an extension of the existing guarantee to United Medical Protection and Australasian Medical Insurance Ltd—that is, to extend their cover to 31 December next year. I hope that, on 3 December next year, I am not standing in this House debating legislation to extend it for another 12 months. It was only on 17 October that we debated legislation to extend the cover to the end of this year. To my way of thinking, that is not the way to handle an issue as important as this one. People need certainty. Doctors need certainty and their patients need certainty. I have to be very critical, because I do not think this delivers that long-term certainty.
There are partial subsidies for insurance premiums for obstetricians, neurosurgeons and GPs performing surgery. That is a most welcome measure. In the area that I represent that has been quite a problem and there has been a great reduction in the number of obstetricians and neurosurgeons. As I highlighted in the speech I made in October, there are only three obstetricians, to the best of my knowledge, working privately in the Newcastle area. This situation has been allowed to develop by a government that is a champion of the private sector. It has encouraged Australian families to take out private health insurance and it has put a lot of money in insurance as opposed to the actual health system. It has failed to provide enough certainty and coverage for obstetricians, and a similar situation exists for neurosurgeons. The number of neurosurgeons in both the Hunter and the Central Coast has declined significantly. Traditionally, the brightest medical students went into specialties like neurosurgery and obstetrics, and now they are steering away from those because of concerns about medical indemnity insurance and cases that could come up in the future.
The government announced a scheme to meet 50 per cent of the cost of claim payments greater than $2 million up to the insured amount made by medical indemnity insurers. There is also a levy to recoup the cost of funding the incurred but not reported, IBNR, liabilities of medical defence organisations that have not set aside money to cover these liabilities. Also, these organisations are to be brought into a new regulatory framework administered by APRA. The ACCC will monitor medical indemnity premiums to determine whether they are actuarial or commercially justifiable. 
This is good, but it is too little too late. While these announcements and this legislation are welcome, unfortunately I do not see that it will solve the problem in the long term. They are short-term measures that seek to stabilise the situation—stabilise the increasing costs of premiums—rather than providing a long-term solution to the problem. These measures are not proactive; they are reactive. They are reacting to a situation that exists now and are not offering a long-term solution. 
One thing that really concerns me is the failure of this package to address the professional indemnity needs of health care professionals such as midwives. In the Hunter there is only one midwife practising privately. She is about to leave the area and will not be replaced. She is moving to northern New South Wales, and it is my understanding that she will not be practising as a midwife because she feels she cannot continue in the current environment. This is a result of the government's failure to address this problem. It has taken away an option for those midwives who are practising privately, particularly in the area of homebirth. I would not like to mislead the parliament: once this midwife leaves there will be no midwives practising or prepared to work in the area of homebirth in the area I represent. The bill also fails to mention issues relating to allied health professionals.
This legislation is a short-term fix, not a long-term solution. I compare the government's handling of this issue to its handling of the bulk-billing issue—it is very similar. In the Shortland electorate in 1999-2000, 78.6 per cent of all medical services were bulk-billed. The latest figures I have show that that has declined to 57 per cent. That is a mammoth decline. Back in 2000, the government commissioned the relative value study of the work performed by GPs. That relative value study showed that the GPs should receive in excess of $40 per consultation. The government failed to act on that, and the AMA and the government were not talking and the issue was not being addressed. That led to a greater decline in bulk-billing services. Who does it hurt? It hurts the families, the pensioners and the veterans that each of us represent in this place. I think the saddest thing of all is that very few GPs are bulk-billing pensioners. All members of this House would know that acceptance of the gold card by GPs is in jeopardy as well.
In my area the decline in bulk-billing has been made worse. That is because one of the first acts of this government was to close a Medicare office that was at least in the vicinity, making it easier for people living in the area to collect their money. They now have to travel a lot further and, particularly where you have an elderly population, that can be a problem because many people have restricted driving licences. I spoke on the telephone with one lady today. She said that her mother, who has been going to a doctor for many years, attended his surgery the other day and was advised that he no longer bulk-billed. Her mother did not know what to do. She had never been to a Medicare office and, because the local Medicare office had been closed, she had to travel some distance. Being 88 years old, the mother had to be driven by the daughter, and the daughter also had to fill out the forms. This caused great anxiety for the mother.
My issue here and how it relates to what we are debating tonight is that, if you allow things to slide, if you do not consult and talk to the people who are involved, the situation will deteriorate. It is very similar to the fact that we have a doctor shortage on the Central Coast in the area that I represent. The desired ratio is one GP per 1,000 people; on the northern part of the Central Coast, there is one GP to every 2,500 people. Certain communities are not only without a doctor who bulk-bills; they are without a doctor—and it is my understanding that the situation is deteriorating. The government promised the allocation of 150 doctors to outlying areas of the six major capital cities; we have seen none being allocated to the area I represent. The government's latest idea of sending failed specialists to work as GPs is not only unacceptable to general practitioners but unacceptable to the people that I and most of us represent in this House. The government refused to act and it refused to negotiate with the GPs—and here we have a crisis relating to bulk-billing. That crisis will continue under this government; it is only the opposition, which is listening to the people, that is prepared to act.
Another thing that I have done is to send a survey out to the people in my electorate of Shortland. To date, I have had 2,500-plus responses to that survey. Overwhelmingly, the most important health issue for my constituents is having a doctor who bulk-bills. Once again, the government has not acted, letting down the people whom I represent in this place. 
Certain things need to be done to resolve the medical indemnity insurance problem. One is that the government needs to show a little more leadership and coordinate national reforms, a national approach. Unfortunately, it has failed to do this. We need uniformity in tort law, and to date this government has not been able to deliver there. It is unable to show leadership. It specialises in creating division and sitting on its hands. We need mandatory reporting of negligence claims and a national data collection of health care negligence cases to help assess where the major problems lie and what the issues are. Until we have that, the problem within the medical system will continue. We really need a government that is prepared to consult, to talk to people.
In Oregon, Oregon Health Services undertook a study—and I mentioned this in a speech I made in the House on 17 October. The spokesman for that project was Larry Baker. In Oregon they found that they were able to dramatically—and I mean really dramatically—reduce the costs of medical negligence claims simply by communicating and talking with people. If the health service there makes a mistake and there is a problem—if a person has a complaint, a relative has been lost or somebody is unsatisfied with the medical treatment they have received—they admit it. Rather than going to ground and refusing to accept responsibility, they admit that they have made a mistake. They talk about it and they resolve the problem. Further to what I have mentioned so far, consideration needs to be given to putting in place a national scheme to ensure long-term care and rehabilitation. A much more active role must be played in keeping reinsurance costs down, working and negotiating with medical defence organisations and improving clinical outcomes.
This legislation should not be considered as a solution to the problem of medical indemnity insurance. Rather, it is a start, and much more is needed. It is a disgrace that here we are, six months down the track, debating this legislation today. It is a disgrace that three months ago we debated legislation that covered us until the end of this year. I certainly hope that this time next year we are not back here debating similar legislation. (Time expired)

name: Draper, Trish, MP
text:
—I welcome the introduction of the Medical Indemnity Bill 2002 and associated bills and I am pleased to have the opportunity to participate in this important debate on medical indemnity insurance. The aim of the government's legislation is to provide for the long-term sustainability and affordability of medical indemnity insurance for Australian doctors. 
Following the placing into liquidation of United Medical Protection and Australasian Medical Insurance Ltd, the government put in place temporary arrangements to ensure that medical services would continue without disruption. The financial situation being experienced by the medical indemnity organisations and the increasing costs of indemnity insurance were cause for strong and decisive action by the government. 
The deterioration in the financial health of the funds is to be lamented. Many questions have been asked, and will continue to be asked, about how they came to find themselves in such a parlous state. Nevertheless, without the government implementing the new measures, the ability of our medical practitioners to continue to provide the vital services they do provide to the Australian people would have suffered greatly. The government has provided a guarantee to cover claims within a specified period, allowing doctors to continue to practise in the knowledge that claims will be met. 
At the same time, the Prime Minister announced the government's proposals for dealing with the unfunded incurred but not reported liabilities—known as IBNRs—of the funds. The Medical Indemnity Bill 2002 has been introduced to deal specifically with this issue. Through this measure, the government will establish which funds have IBNRs and have failed to set aside money to cover their liabilities. The government will then fund these liabilities but will recoup this cost through a levy on the fund's members which will be payable over an extended period. This levy will apply only to those funds which have not funded their IBNRs. Doctors who are members of a medical indemnity organisation that has funded its IBNRs will not be subject to the levy. This is the only fair and equitable way of resolving this issue. It would not be right for the Australian taxpayer to carry the entire burden; at the same time, without this funding doctors would have faced much higher premiums which they would have been forced to pay over a short period. 
By this measure, the government has made the cost of funding these liabilities more affordable. Doctors who have to pay the levy because their medical indemnity organisation has not funded its IBNRs will have several options. They can pay the levy in a lump sum and enjoy a discount, they can pay by instalments or they can defer payment for a year. The levy, which is tax deductible, will probably run over five years; the annual amount which a doctor pays will be limited to 50 per cent of their 2000-01 premium.
To properly safeguard doctors in the future, the medical indemnity organisations will now be subjected to a range of prudential safeguards to reduce the risk of their insolvency. A new regulatory framework will be established by the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority. From now on, medical indemnity organisations must report their IBNRs on their balance sheets and make provision for them.
Let us be quite clear on this. In the past some organisations had not provided adequately for their incurred but not reported liabilities. Some have seen the error of this and in recent years have changed their financial practices to ensure that all of their liabilities are fully funded. As a result of the government's strong actions, all medical indemnity organisations will now have to not only show the level of all of their liabilities but also make adequate provision for them. It is important for the sake of the medical profession to maintain choice in the provision of medical indemnity insurance. The competitive marketplace usually provides the most affordable and best quality service available, with an appropriate regulatory framework.
In order to safeguard the public by ensuring that doctors can continue to practise with adequate medical indemnity insurance cover, the government has strengthened the regulatory requirements. At the same time it has provided the means by which the mistakes of the past can be paid for fairly and affordably. 
The government has also been mindful of the problem of increasing costs of medical indemnity insurance premiums. This legislation will ease the pressure on doctors, through the high-cost claims scheme, under which the government will provide assistance for the cost of large claims. Medical indemnity organisations will pay out less on big claims, leading to a reduction in the amount of reinsurance they have to purchase, and this should have a positive effect on premiums.
The bill also provides for premium subsidies for specific groups of doctors who undertake high-risk specialties but whose expertise and service to their patients are vital. These doctors have suffered from particularly large increases in their premiums during recent times, and the government will provide subsidies to help them afford the cost of their premiums while the broader reform package takes full effect. This will serve to address a key concern of many medical practitioners.
Ultimately the sustainability of the medical indemnity insurance industry depends on improving patient safety. I understand that, after consultation with medical professionals and their industry representatives, the minister has been encouraged by their desire and willingness to improve clinical risk management and reduce the incidence of patient injury.
At the local level, I have seen the willingness of health professionals to improve the care and safety of their patients through the introduction of prescribing safeguards in an aged care facility in my electorate. A joint project between the University of South Australia, Helping Hand Aged Care and the Adelaide North East Division of General Practice will provide doctors caring for patients with the Helping Hand Aged Care facilities with access to the same prescribing information that is available in their surgeries. The benefit to residents will come from the improved levels of safety and quality in the prescribing of their medicines. 
Medication errors, and their often adverse effects, are a problem which occurs not only in Australia but throughout the world. It is particularly pleasing to see that one solution to this problem is being implemented here in South Australia. Dr Chris Bollen of the Adelaide North East Division of General Practice has advised me that the idea for this project came about as a result of his reading the recommendations of the Australian Council for Safety and Quality in Health Care, a federal government initiative. It is always pleasing to see that the valuable expert advice and information generated by such bodies is utilised effectively within our community. I wish to personally congratulate Dr Bollen and Professor Jim Warren of the University of South Australia. Thanks must also go to the dedicated management, Dr Milton Hart and staff, whose hard work and enthusiasm for this project have seen it become a reality. For residents of Helping Hand Aged Care, it must be a comfort to know that their interests are being well served by so many talented people.
Finally, in dealing with claims made by patients against their doctors, we must recognise that such matters need to be kept in a proper perspective. As with other areas of tort law, we must not go down the American path of excessively high levels of litigation. We are, unfortunately, becoming a more litigious society and doctors are just as human as the rest of us: mistakes will be made no matter how careful and cautious we are. Moves to allow medical professionals to offer an apology to patients or the patient's family without condemning himself or herself to a financial malpractice suit are steps in the right direction. It may be an often used phrase, but a little bit of basic commonsense is what may be lacking in some instances, along with a little humanity and understanding. These bills address some of the underlying structural problems of the medical indemnity insurance industry and will reduce the pressure on premiums that doctors have to pay. Ultimately it will be for the state and territory jurisdictions to tackle the problems of tort law reform which are at the heart of this issue. As the chair of the health and aged care committee, I commend the bills to the House.

name: O'Connor, Gavan, MP
text:
—The Medical Indemnity Bill 2002 and associated bills which we are debating in the House tonight give effect to significant elements of the government's policy on medical indemnity insurance which were announced on 23 October 2002. These bills are a response to a crisis situation in the medical profession that should have been reasonably anticipated by the government. Once again, the incompetence of this government has been seriously exposed by the public record of events in relation to this complex area of medical indemnity insurance. 
These bills contain three important measures to assist the medical profession in addressing the issue of steeply rising medical insurance premiums and they introduce a measure of certainty and stability to the medical insurance market. In typical fashion, the debacle in the medical insurance area mirrors what has happened in many policy areas where this government and its ministers, in their incompetence, have failed to act decisively to head off crises and collapses in the corporate area. At the end of the day, that incompetence has cost industry dearly and a huge burden has been placed on ordinary Australians. In the collapse of HIH, the Treasurer and his prudential regulator failed in their administrative duty. The pieces of the Treasurer's incompetence are still being picked up by football clubs, pony clubs, local governments, tourism businesses and doctors. 
In the Ansett and OneTel collapses, the government ministers were asleep at the wheel, and there were horrendous impacts on the lives of employees and, in Ansett's case, on regional businesses which were particularly reliant on the continued operation of that airline. There is one disturbing characteristic of these collapses and crises: the sheer incompetence of government ministers in failing to act decisively in emergency crises. Now we can add another crisis to the list: the crisis in medical indemnity insurance.  
In announcing a package to meet the ongoing crisis, the government outlined a number of measures to address the problems that have emerged in the medical indemnity insurance field. They are an extension of the existing guarantee to United Medical Protection and Australasian Medical Insurance Ltd to 31 December 2003; partial subsidies for insurance premiums for obstetricians, neurosurgeons and GPs performing procedures; a scheme to meet 50 per cent of the cost of claim payments greater than $2 million, up to the insured amount, made by medical indemnity insurers; funding of the incurred but not reported liabilities for those medical defence organisations that have not set aside money to cover these liabilities; a levy to recoup the cost of funding for IBNR liabilities for members of the relevant medical defence organisations over an extended period; medical defence organisations to be brought into a new regulatory framework administered by the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority; and the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission to monitor medical indemnity insurance premiums to determine whether they are actuarially and commercially justified.
This package of bills gives effect to basically three elements of the October announcements. Firstly, it provides a scheme to assist those medical defence organisations which have unfunded incurred but not reported liabilities as at 30 June 2002 to meet those claims when they come onstream. Secondly, it provides a high-cost claims scheme aimed at lowering premiums by reducing the high cost of claims related to medical incidents. Thirdly, it provides a subsidy to obstetricians, neurosurgeons and GPs who undertake Medicare billable procedures. 
I do not propose to canvass the complexity of these bills. Suffice it to say that, had the government acted earlier to address this crisis, the Australian taxpayer might have been spared the $246.5 million outlay over four years that is now required to address the very serious problems that emerged in the medical insurance indemnity market. The opposition will support the bill, but we have moved a second reading amendment that offers some scope for debate and discussion on matters affecting the provision and cost of medical indemnity insurance to GPs and other medical specialists, and other associated matters. As members appreciate, the services provided by doctors are not always provided in hospitals or surgeries. Doctors are called on at the scene of emergencies, in the home when a person is taken seriously ill or is convalescing, and in places such as nursing homes and hostels where care to the aged is delivered. 
In the case of the latter, the ongoing quality of care and the physical safety of the aged are important elements of the total package of care provided by doctors, health care professionals and aged care providers within the ambit of their establishments. Regrettably, in recent years there has been an ongoing problem in maintaining and improving standards of care in many aged care establishments. This factor, coupled with the uncertainty created for doctors by the medical indemnity crisis, has led some GPs and specialists to question whether they are able to maintain a regime of regular visits to older people who reside in certain aged care establishments.
Last night in the adjournment debate in this House I raised on behalf of constituents very serious matters relating to a proposal to extend the Glenburn nursing home in Drumcondra in my electorate. In that speech I raised two major questions relating to the process of planning approval for the extension of that facility and the granting of a licence for 30 extra beds at the facility. I said in that speech that the two central questions that I raised spawned a myriad of ancillary questions relating to council approval processes, planning considerations, VCAT deliberations, care and safety of the aged at Glenburn, residents' rights and the appropriateness of nursing home developments in the region. I do not propose to canvass all of those matters here; however, I would like to refer to one aspect—the care and safety of older people at Glenburn nursing home should this development proceed, because it raises the sorts of care issues of real concern to doctors and other health professionals involved with the care of the aged at this nursing home and similar facilities and their reluctance to provide that care in potentially risky environments. 
The government allocated 30 extra beds to Glenburn following a submission for 30 additional beds, which was prepared by Mr Chris Whitehead on behalf of the proprietor, Jeff Alexander, and the company that runs the Glenburn nursing home. In August 2000, a site audit was done of the Glenburn nursing home, and Mr Whitehead was part of that assessment team. The facility in question is a nursing home which is currently located in a residential area. The proposed extension would see this facility expanded to incorporate a two-storey facility located in that area. There are serious questions being asked as to how the facility was able to get through the planning processes. There are legitimate concerns expressed by the residents of my electorate. They have also raised very important and serious concerns about this two-storey nursing home development in a residential area where parking is restricted and where the fire safety provisions can be questioned. They also raise concerns about the ultimate care of clients in this facility.
I raised this nursing home as an example because I have had doctors who service clients in that facility complain about the risks that will exist for older people in that extended facility, and they have told me of their own reluctance, if this development should proceed, to service older people in that environment. I would like to reinforce the concerns of those doctors who have raised the issue of medical indemnity insurance should they be forced into a situation of discharging their medical duty to their older patients and servicing those patients in what they regard as inappropriate aged care establishments. In a letter to Minister Andrews about the proposed development, local resident Mrs Lois Trounson said:
I have lived at my present address for over 60 years and the proposed nursing home would back on to my backyard. I am at a loss to understand why someone who has been pursued through the AAT, Supreme Court, High Supreme Court, back to the AAT, to close him down in Tasmania and attempt to wind him up in Geelong can have an application for 30 additional beds and funding approved.
This is a constituent referring to an aged care facility in which older people reside and which doctors have said to me they may not service because of the risks associated with the older people residing in this expanded facility. Mrs Trounson continues:
Another great concern to me is the fact that the developer has gained a permit for a facility that the CFA has indicated could pose a huge problem in the event of a fire. They have stated that they would be unable to gain access to the rear of the property via the back lane—the only means of access. I am 94 years old and would be very uncomfortable knowing that I was on a second storey of a building, which, if it caught fire, would pose a real problem for firefighters to gain access—and I am not a nursing home candidate. Therefore I hold very real fears for the welfare of the patients should this facility proceed.
That is a concern that has been echoed by a doctor who lives in the same street as this nursing home and who is frequently called on to attend the residents of that nursing home. Mrs Trounson goes on to say in her letter:
There is a great deal of far more desirable locations in the Geelong area for the hospital. These alternate locations would provide a superior quality of life (eg. greenery, larger bedrooms, bathrooms, lounge areas etc.) rather than cramming this facility in an already busy neighbourhood, and on [an] already extremely busy road. The proposed setting is totally inappropriate for many more reasons than the ones I have stated.
Those reasons have been brought to my attention by a whole range of constituents in this locality who are concerned about this development. The most interesting objection has come from doctors who service the facility now, who see real dangers for nursing home residents should this expansion proceed in this residential area and who have questioned, in the face of this medical indemnity insurance crisis, whether they have the capacity in the future—in what they perceive to be a medically and physically risky environment—to service the needs of the residents of that particular facility. 
I mention this because in so many ways the medical indemnity insurance crisis is affecting ordinary Australians. The shadow minister has outlined in debate how this particular crisis could undermine bulk-billing—the pillar, the cornerstone, of Medicare, that great Labor initiative and universal health scheme that has won the endorsement of Australians over several decades. It is very important that we retain that Medicare system and bulk-billing, and it is very important that we overcome this particular crisis in medical indemnity insurance—because it has the potential, over time, to undermine one of the great health insurance and health care systems in the world.
I raise these matters related to the Glenburn nursing home because I think they add a certain dimension to this debate. The dimension is simply this: doctors in my community—in the place where I live—have raised some very serious objections to the expansion of this facility at its present location. They have not objected to the relocation of this facility to a new, alternative area that is more appropriate; they are saying that the residents of that nursing home at this time, and future residents, may well be at risk should that development proceed. If it does proceed then they would seriously consider, given the current medical indemnity insurance arrangements, whether or not they would be able to provide services to the older people in that environment. It is a serious issue. It is a local dimension, if you like, to this debate.
Today I met with the Minister for Ageing on this matter and I must say I was heartened by the discussions I had with him. He listened attentively to the points that I made with regard to this nursing home and he gave an undertaking to examine the matter to its fullest extent. I should also acknowledge here the contribution of the member for Corangamite on this issue. Although his electorate is on the other side of the Barwon River, he has taken an interest in the issue and has also made approaches to the minister, which I am grateful for. The honourable member for Corangamite and I, as many members would know, have had many stoushes on the floor of this House, on a range of issues. But on some issues we do come together in the interests of the community of Geelong. This may not seem a big issue to some but it is an important issue. It is important because it relates to the care provided by doctors to older Australians—doctors who question their ability to deliver that care under current medical indemnity insurance arrangements. We will be supporting the general thrust of this legislation before the House because it is necessary in order to underpin the provision of medical services to working Australians on an ongoing basis.

name: Hartsuyker, Luke, MP
text:
—I rise in the House to speak on the issue of provision of medical indemnity insurance. The four bills that the government has put before the House provide security to doctors and stability for the provision of health care in Australia. There has been great concern in the community over the issue of medical indemnity insurance, and the government has acted to address these concerns. The Medical Indemnity Bill 2002, the Medical Indemnity (Consequential Amendments) Bill 2002, the Medical Indemnity (Enhanced UMP Indemnity) Contribution Bill 2002 and the Medical Indemnity (IBNR Indemnity) Contribution Bill 2002 act to address the issue of medical indemnity.
The federal coalition has an outstanding record in addressing the health needs of all Australians and in particular the needs of people in rural and regional Australia. The issue of medical indemnity insurance is of course an important matter that the federal government has made a priority since the collapse of United Medical Protection. These bills currently before the House will assist in reducing the cost of medical insurance and ensure that medical services, particularly in regional and rural Australia, are maintained.
The National Party and this government are absolutely committed to ensuring that first-class medical services are provided to the people of regional and rural Australia. This is evidenced by the regional health strategy announced in the 2000 budget, which provided $562 million over four years to improve access to health services for people living in regional and rural areas. No other Commonwealth government has ever invested such a significant amount of funding to enable long-term systematic reform of rural and regional health services. The regional health strategy builds on the success of the coalition's many innovations in rural health such as the GP retention program, the John Flynn scholarship and other landmark initiatives to get more doctors and services into country areas.  
There are a number of issues which the National Party has pushed for and the federal government has adopted in their focus on improving health services in rural and regional areas. The regional health strategy provides $210 million over four years to increase the number of doctors, specialists and allied health professionals working in country Australia. These initiatives include $102.1 million to increase the number of GPs in regional Australia. This year, 200 out of 450 vocational postgraduate training places for general practice will be located in regional and rural Australia resulting in an immediate increase in access to GP services for those in the country.
Another initiative is the registrars program for trainee specialist GPs who can earn an extra $60,000 over three years by training in a rural area. The strategy includes $48.4 million for greater specialist access in regional Australia, including funding for incentives and travel costs for specialists to conduct outreach specialty work and to act as mentors for local health professionals to help them increase their skills.
There is $49.5 million to fund increased allied health services in country Australia. Physiotherapy, nursing, podiatry and psychology will be provided to assist local GPS in caring for their community. The government also implemented the Rural Retention Program in 1999—a world first initiative which rewards long-serving doctors with annual bonuses based on the length of their service and the remoteness of their practice. This $60 million program is to assist rural communities to keep their doctors. To date, payments totalling approximately $20 million have been paid to over 1,600 GPs in regional and rural Australia. But the retention of highly skilled health professionals in regional areas will become all the more difficult, unless it is backed by these medical indemnity bills.
It is important to note that some of the programs which are now in place are initiatives which will increase the level of health services provided to country Australia. We must remember that the delivery of health services in such areas is dependent on an integrated approach which spreads across all professionals involved in medical care. For example, having a viable medical indemnity insurance market will allow our nurses to continue their good work. As many of our colleagues will be aware, for the first time ever the federal government is providing support for practice nurses to improve the level of care Australians receive. The 2001 budget announced $104.3 million to allow general practices to employ more nurses, especially benefiting those living in regional and outer metropolitan areas.
Additionally, $13 million is funding 100 new nursing scholarships worth $10,000 each to encourage more students with a regional and rural background to study nursing and to address the shortage of nurses in country areas. We have also seen the establishment of rural work force agencies in each state and the Northern Territory to look at the needs of different remote communities and help them recruit and retain their doctors through a range of initiatives. This support is worth approximately $14 million per year.
To assist in delivering more doctors to rural and regional Australia, the regional health strategy provides $162 million over four years to support rural GPs' training and educational needs. The initiatives include nine new clinical schools and three new university departments of rural health being established at a cost of $117.6 million. This announcement has complemented the seven university departments that the government has established in each state and the Northern Territory since 1996 to focus on issues associated with rural health work force development. The clinical schools will ensure that senior-year medical students receive comprehensive training in the practice and procedures they will need for rural practice. There is $32.4 million from the regional health strategy to create 100 scholarships worth $20,000 per year for medical students willing to practice in rural areas for a period of at least six years. Funding will also be provided to create 100 new places within university medical schools around the country. 
Also, $8 million has been provided under the Rural Australia Medical Undergraduate Scholarship Scheme to enable more students with a rural background to undertake medical training. This extra funding effectively doubles the number of places available to 400. Medical graduates have the opportunity to work off their HECS debt. One-fifth of the HECS debt will be forgone for each year worked in a designated regional area at a cost of some $4.3 million. The government has extended the John Flynn scholarship to ensure that this year nearly 600 medical students will receive financial support to work in a country environment with a doctor mentor. The coalition established the James Cook University Medical School in Townsville at a cost of $10 million and the University of New South Wales Clinical School in Wagga at a cost of $13.2 million.
The value of all of these initiatives depends on the existence of an affordable medical insurance market. The absence of a solid and acceptable medical indemnity insurance market effectively eliminates the incentive for many professionals to work. This would place at risk many of the services I have just mentioned which have been introduced at great expense to improve the level of service provision in regional and rural Australia.
There is a range of other issues, such as $68.9 million to expand the Regional Health Services Program; $41.6 million would be spent on rural pharmacy maintenance allowance to provide assistance for the start-up of pharmacies and also to assist in keeping existing pharmacies; and small non-government hospitals in rural areas will be assisted by the $30.3 million funding being used to revitalise bush nursing hospitals to refurbish, restructure, be run more efficiently and enhance the quality of care they offer their remote communities. The strategy also allocates $14.2 million to develop and implement the chronic disease support package for small rural and regional communities to deal with conditions such as asthma, diabetes, renal failure and depression. Another $32 million was committed to increase the Medicare rebate for other medical practitioners—GPs who are not vocationally registered who practise in rural and regional Australia.
In the 2001-02 budget, the coalition allocated $43.4 million to establish 32 after-hours primary medical care sites across Australia. These sites will be set up in collaboration with local GPs and will aim to provide additional services to predominantly outer metropolitan and rural areas where current access and services are poor. The measures I have mentioned demonstrate, as I have said previously, the depth of commitment this government has to providing health services in regional and rural areas. Country services are disproportionately affected by the increases in medical indemnity insurance because of the low volume of some procedures compared to city practices. We must support our rural health initiatives with reforms in the area of medical indemnity.
This package of bills focuses on premium affordability for doctors and on ensuring the viability of medical indemnity organisations or MDOs into the future. The Medical Indemnity Bill 2002 will provide for determining which medical defence organisations have unfunded incurred but not reported liabilities—IBNRs. It will also allow the Commonwealth to make payments in relation to claims forming part of the unfunded IBNR liability of MDOs as at 30 June 2002 and in relation to high-cost claims and subsidies for certain medical practitioners. I know that health professionals who practise in the Cowper electorate are facing increased costs in premiums because of substantial insurance payouts.
These bills will allow the Commonwealth to make payments for part of the costs of large claims against MDOs or medical indemnity insurers in relation to incidents notified after 1 January 2003. Subsidies will also be accessible to assist medical practitioners, specifically neurosurgeons, obstetricians and gynaecologists, to meet the cost of indemnity coverage. An administrative mechanism will be established to support levies on doctors to pay for the IBNR scheme and the enhanced UMP guarantee. The Medical Indemnity (IBNR Indemnity) Contribution Bill 2002 supports the levy for the IBNR scheme on doctors in those MDOs with unfunded liabilities. The Medical Indemnity (Enhanced UMP Indemnity) Contribution Bill 2002 allows for a levy on UMP members to cover the cost to the Commonwealth of any payment under the deed of indemnity between the Commonwealth, UMP, Australasian Medical Insurance Limited or AMIL and the provisional liquidator of UMP-AMIL. The Medical Indemnity (Consequential Amendments) Bill 2002 will provide for amendments to other acts necessary as a result of the medical indemnity bills. 
The government's incurred but not reported scheme will assist those MDOs which have unfunded IBNRs as at 30 June 2002 to pay those claims when they crystallise. The Commonwealth will help these MDOs to pay claims for which they had not adequately provisioned in the past. This scheme will give affected MDOs the chance of a fresh start, unencumbered by past unfunded IBNRs. The IBNR scheme consists of two parts. Firstly, the Commonwealth will provide funding for MDO IBNR liabilities that are unfunded as at 30 June 2002, with payouts beginning in early 2003. Secondly, it will recoup the cost of funding those liabilities through a levy on members of the MDOs with unfunded IBNRs. It is important to note that the members of medical defence organisations whose incurred but not reported claims are fully funded as at 30 June 2002 will not pay the levy. It is also important to note—and I know medical practitioners in the Cowper electorate will welcome this—that those who belong to medical defence organisations that have fully provisioned for their IBNRs will not be subject to the levy. For those practitioners who are liable to pay the levy, it will be set as a proportion; the maximum will equal 50 per cent of the medical indemnity premium they paid in the 2000-01 financial year. This means that it will reflect the risks borne by different practitioner groups—an approach that is strongly favoured by medical organisations.
In this package of bills the Commonwealth will also introduce a scheme, known as the High Cost Claims Scheme, to address the issue of high cost claims related to medical incidents. We are all aware of some of the recently reported landmark claims, and this scheme attempts to address the quantum of these claims. The scheme should lower premiums by reducing the potential cost of large claims to insurers. Under this scheme, the Commonwealth will meet 50 per cent of the cost of claims for payments greater than $2 million, and up to the insured amount, made by medical indemnity insurers. This scheme will apply to claims notified on or after 1 January 2003. It will not apply to claims relating to the provision of public hospital services. By meeting 50 per cent of the cost of payouts over $2 million by medical indemnity providers in relation to high cost claims, the Commonwealth is working to ensure, among other things, that adequate cover is available where incidents result in catastrophic injuries to patients. This scheme is also an effective way to address the exposure and uncertainty associated with high cost claims in medical indemnity insurance.
Premium affordability, and the consequent impacts on service provision, is a vital issue for medical practitioners, particularly in regional and rural Australia. The National Party and, indeed, the government are absolutely committed to ensure that health care providers are not restricted by prohibitive premiums in their service delivery in regional areas. If you take away the incentive to provide the care, you jeopardise the service delivery right across the nation. This particularly applies to specialists in regional areas who are facing high premiums, but who may not have the volume of clients that their metropolitan based colleagues experience. This package puts in place the foundations of the Commonwealth's subsidy scheme for doctors. 
The subsidy scheme will be applied in the following ways. The subsidy will be provided to obstetricians, neurosurgeons and GP proceduralists who undertake Medicare billable procedures. It will be equivalent to 50 per cent of the difference between the cost of their premiums, plus the IBNR levy if applicable, and the corresponding costs for gynaecologists, general surgeons and non-procedural GPs respectively in the relevant state and territory. In light of the particularly high premium costs faced by some neurosurgeons, combined with their relatively limited scope to derive income from private practice, the subsidy rate will increase to 80 per cent on that portion of their premium, plus levy if applicable, that exceeds $50,000. Accessing the subsidy will be conditional on medical practitioners participating in quality and safety programs designed to protect patients and minimise the incidence of injuries. Approaches will be examined to minimise the need for rural doctors to be absent from their practices. 
The federal coalition has shown true leadership in addressing the medical indemnity issues which have confronted doctors for the last year. We have provided a guarantee to those medical practitioners who were left exposed following the collapse of UMP-AMIL. That guarantee has now been extended to the end of 2003 to allow UMP-AMIL to make payments under cover to members and provide security during the formulation of a long-term strategy for the industry.
Today we have before us the bills which will put in place a framework which will provide security for those who provide health care right across the nation. I know my constituents of Cowper will welcome the positive outcomes which these bills will bring to our electorate. As I detailed previously, the coalition government has a proud record of addressing the challenges of providing improved health care for all Australians, particularly for those who live in rural and regional areas. When you look right across the spectrum of health care in regional areas, there are programs in place to improve the delivery of medical services: incentives for rural doctors, the education of medical staff and now, with these bills, improvements in the field of medical indemnity. All these initiatives show leadership in improving one of our key priorities—the provision of better health care, particularly in regional areas.
It is therefore essential that we embrace these medical indemnity bills to make sure that insurance is affordable and that we can provide medical practitioners with the security to carry on providing first-class services to all Australians. Considerable work has been done by this government in taking the lead in tort law reform. I believe these bills, working in conjunction with tort law reform by the states, should work to substantially improve the situation in relation to medical indemnity. I must say I was pleased to hear the member for Corio offering his support for these very important bills. I commend these bills to the House.

name: Hatton, Michael, MP
text:
— The Medical Indemnity Bill 2002, the Medical Indemnity (Consequential Amendments) Bill 2002, theMedical Indemnity (Enhanced UMP Indemnity) Contribution Bill 2002 and, last but by no means least, the Medical Indemnity (IBNR Indemnity) Contribution Bill 2002 are an interesting set of bills. This very important set of cognate bills is enough to rivet the attention of the member for Parramatta, the parliamentary secretary at the table! The member for Parramatta has seen this parliament deal with cognate bills time after time, and it has been a case of, `Well, you may as well do them as a job lot rather than take up the time of the parliament dealing with one bill after another seriatim.' Of course, these bills do share a concordance in terms of the problem that they are trying to address, but they also share a concordance in terms of what they underline as the insufficiencies (1) of the government, (2) of the medical insurance industry as a whole and (3) of insurance in Australia generally. 
These bills highlight the government's inability as a government that does not believe in being hands-on—despite the philosophical ramifications that the member for Parramatta has attempted to introduce into the coalition: the fundamental notions of what a Liberal Party should undertake as an engaged entity, taking a Benthamite approach to trying to ensure the greatest good for the greatest number, trying to reinvigorate the party's notion of the core reality that John Stuart Mill was talking about in his great exposition On Liberty, which the member for Parramatta and others in the coalition are very au fait with. The redefinition of liberalism, which the parliamentary secretary at the table has had a great deal to do with, does not go far enough, because it cannot adequately capture the problems that there are in the market, despite the fact that the member for Parramatta is not only enamoured of the libertarian approaches taken by Bentham and Mill but also those of Adam Smith. The core and fundamental problem with Adam Smith was that his faith in the market was misplaced. Adam Smith did not understand that unregulated markets do not lead to eternal good—you need a sense of participatory regulation from a governmental entity to actually make the thing work competitively and to make it work properly and profitably for all involved. 
Now that we have got the attention of the parliamentary secretary, despite the fact that he is actually wandering from the table to consult the Deputy Speaker, we might deal with these cognate bills and what they throw up in terms of the problems not only that society has had but also that the government has had in coming to terms with it. The medical profession in Australia is extremely important, and not only in Sydney. Bankstown airport, in my electorate, is at the geographical centre point of Sydney. The member for Parramatta understands that, because he is just outside the locus of the centre of Sydney, which is, as I said, in the electorate of Blaxland, Parramatta being proximate. The member for Lingiari, who is at the table representing the ALP, understands that medical indemnity is very important for regional Australia.
 (Mr Barresi)—Order! There is too much audible chatter in the chamber.
—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. I could not hear them, but your hearing is very acute. It is another medical matter we might deal with as we deal with these bills! When we are dealing with these issues, we are dealing not only with central metropolitan concerns, such as in Sydney, which affect Blaxland and Parramatta, but with issues which affect regional Australia—and indeed remote Australia in the case of the member for Lingiari. He is a great proponent of the need for greater resources to be centred in regional and remote Australia to deal with the particular problems that his constituents face.
But what we face here in this cognate series of bills is a fundamental failing systemically; a fundamental failing of this government; a fundamental failing of the free market system that has so readily been apprehended and embraced by the member for Parramatta—the good parliamentary secretary that he is, the failed interjector that he is—
—Why are you pushing him forward?
—I am pushing him forward, mate, in order to knock him down. That is just a debating point.
 (Mr Barresi)—The member for Blaxland will not respond to the interjections.
—The member for Parramatta understands in a primitive way that the free market economy cannot be embraced on its own. In the period of mercantilism—embracing the late 17th century to the early 18th century and into the 19th century when mercantilism merged into the great age of industrialism between 1870 and 1900—what was laid open and bare to the bone was that market forces on their own, untrammelled, led to great social ills. That was apparent in the United Kingdom and the United States. It was even apparent in probably the most significant, powerful and forceful of the 1870 to 1900 industrialisers—Germany, both Prussia and the associated states. They understood that there was enormous power in education, that there was enormous power in governmental activity and that there was probably more power in that than there was in what was put forward in the US and in Britain in the ideology of mercantilism transposed into the new and unfettered industrialism.
The Germans realised fundamentally that there was a place for the government, there was a place for a bureaucratic element and there was also a place for ensuring the end results of what governments chose to do. In doing that, in arguing that there was a place in the modern era for what we understand as a public-private partnership, they were arguing that the excesses of the late 19th century in the rogue capitalism of the United States and to a lesser extent Britain showed that you cannot have an untrammelled market—you could, but it probably would not be successful. Certainly you should not have a supposedly free market where the operations of the free market do not really work. 
In the cognate bills that we are dealing with we are faced with a very simple problem. If you simply argue that government should get out of the area and should leave it to private industry, you cannot do it in one way only. People did argue this during the Fraser period—people like the current Prime Minister, the member for Bennelong. He argued it as an unsuccessful Treasurer, one who lost almost every battle he had to the quite socialist Fraser—that is how Malcolm Fraser is regarded as being at that time, and in fact he is regarded as being increasingly socialist with the passing of the years. 
If you took the point of view of the member for Bennelong from 1974 through to the crucial period 1978 to February-March 1983—a period in which he failed on point after point in trying to introduce his philosophies—you would see that you cannot do it one way only. You cannot give everything to the market and expect markets to work unencumbered and to work with perfection. Even the member for Parramatta would not expect that, given the fact that the member for Parramatta has thought about these things deeply, more so than many of his colleagues, I think. It is not an unreflective acceptance of either Mill, Burke—even as a conservative—or any of the other people in the current pantheon that has taken so much of a hold.
There is a fundamental reality here: if you do not pay in, you do not get anything back. The government is faced with not just a market failure; the government is faced with pure greed, pure exploitation and pure selfishness on the part of those medical practitioners who thought they had a good thing going in keeping the little racket they had organised for themselves—the fact that they could do medical indemnity insurance on the cheap. If you are going to do medical insurance on the cheap, there are some people who are going to be worse off—our constituents. They will be the ones who will suffer in the end. The government may also have to suffer in the end because it has to grapple with the inadequacies of what has been put up.
This is a wonderful illustration of the disconjunction between ideology and ideological approaches to things and the fundamental, practical accounting and economic realities that any organisation, any institution or any association may face. It seemed a good idea at the time for the surgeons and the practitioners to put their money into the central organisation that provided most of the funds to cover medical insurance. It was reasonable; it did not overtax them. They sort of realised that it was done on the cheap but it was a good thing at the time. We found when reality came knocking at the door that the arrangements were not right; the arrangements were transparently problematic.
Constituents of the member for Parramatta, the member for Lingiari, those who have spoken before in this debate—nay, even Deputy Speaker Barresi, who is in the chair—have realised that, without adequate resources to our local hospitals, our local GPs, our local specialists and those they refer us to in life-threatening situations, our lives are held cheaply. They are held cheaply because a number of people—indeed, possibly the majority—in the medical profession thought that the deal that they were offered was too hard to refuse, that it was cheap but good, and that it might last forever.
That is a natural reaction of most people. Indeed, we see it in the parliament day after day, week after week, in the person of the Treasurer: that sort of hopeful optimism that projects whatever the current circumstances are almost exponentially into the future. We have seen it in past governments as well. But if you project current circumstances indefinitely, you will be fundamentally wrong. The medical insurance companies that failed projected current circumstances well into the future. They underprojected the demands on their funds and resources. In the end they left a set of medical practitioners high and dry because they did not tell them the truth. They were not laid open, as they would lay their patients open in surgery or under the knife in the theatre, to the practical realities of the medical situation they faced. They were not laid open to the bare accounting realities of how much money they would have to front up with in insurance terms to adequately cover their insurance risk. 
This has nothing to do with the twin towers and it effectively has nothing to do with the other great area of unanswered responsibility: the question of public liability Australia wide. This has to do with a closed profession with a closed mind and a closed set of insurers who would not confront reality. This government, which does not believe in public intervention, in 1996 quite openly had a paper published that was, from memory, about one inch thick. It was wonderful and shiny, with a bright yellow cover to attract the attention of the parliamentary secretary, the Deputy Speaker or anyone else in the parliament and the National Commission of Audit. The paper basically laid out that a coalition federal government would have nothing to do with direct services to any individual in Australia because it thought its whole game was to get out of public enterprise and public responsibility.
I know that deep down in his heart of hearts the member for Parramatta would know—as the Deputy Speaker, Mr Barresi, would know—that you cannot run away from reality. You cannot run away from public responsibility. There was a dysfunctional fault line at the centre of this. It was that, if no-one else fronted up to the realities of the situation, in the end the Australian buck would stop at the doorstep of the Prime Minister and this parliament. That is why we are faced with the Medical Indemnity Bill 2002, the Medical Indemnity (Consequential Amendments) Bill 2002, the Medical Indemnity (Enhanced UMP Indemnity) Contribution Bill 2002 and the Medical Indemnity (IBNR Indemnity) Contribution Bill 2002.
There has been a total failure not only of the market in terms of medical insurance but also of the marketeers. There has been a total failure of the insurers who had a responsibility not only to the medical practitioners who put their funds with them but also to the patients who, in the end, were reliant on them for cover for the medical practitioners' uses. People went to Bankstown Hospital, Liverpool Hospital or any of the great hospitals in Sydney—or, indeed, to the great hospital in Alice Springs, in the case of the member for Lingiari—to have surgery for life-threatening cases. They did not want to think too much in terms of medical responsibility and medical indemnity. If they had paid their money into private insurance or had rightly been paying their tax funds into Medicare, they would expect that, if they had life-threatening conditions, their surgeons would be there to save their lives.
If there is one fundamental in the health area, it is that you can expect that our professionals—acting professionally and supported by a medical indemnity insurance regime that cossets and protects them—are able to do their jobs to save our lives and protect the lives of our families and friends; and that they will not have to put their professional integrity on the line to ensure that they can do their jobs. This government—unwillingly, let it be said—has been forced, in this set of cognate bills, to deal with the fact that the Australian medical profession failed. They failed to pay their money up front to cover themselves. They failed to ensure that their key insurer did the job it should have been doing from day one. It should have been covering not only the medical profession's responsibilities and liabilities but also all of their patients, so that we could be assured that if we fell into difficulties—whether we were on the Labor side or the coalition side and whatever our views on the market and government intervention—then the Australian medical system and Australian medical insurance would cover us. Our doctors should have been willing to pay a high enough premium to cover themselves but also a set of premiums that was reasonable.
It is not sufficient to argue that all you have to do is cover yourself in these situations. We have had a fundamental failure of the market here. We have had that failure because the market participants were given an easy ride. They did not have to pay out the proper amounts. They did not have to contribute in order to ensure their relative safety was covered through insurance. So, in the end, the buck stops with the Australian people. In the end, all of the jargon, all of the argument and all of the ideological approaches—whether they be Mill, the more conservative Burke or the rest of the pantheon the coalition looks to—fail. Markets always fail. Markets without government intervention and government underwriting fundamentally fail. We are here picking up the pieces and putting in the dollars because of a market failure. These bills attempt to redress it. (Time expired)

name: Cobb, John, MP
text:
—In rising to speak on the Medical Indemnity Bill 2002 and related bills, I have to say that I am not going to be able to call up antecedents from the 16th and 17th centuries as the previous speaker, the member for Blaxland, did. But, against what the member for Corio and the member for Shortland may have said earlier, the government has to be congratulated for showing leadership in two areas: medical indemnity and public liability in general. Those are two areas that obviously have got out of control, and the government has held national summits to deal with them. For somebody with an electorate like mine, absolutely nothing is more important than having a health system—and a specialist system, which is probably more to the point in this debate—that can support our communities, whether we need obstetrics, neurosurgery or specialist GP services, so that we know we have somewhere we can go. In an electorate like mine, which goes from Broken Hill to Dubbo to Parkes, you do not have that many choices about where you can go for these kinds of specialist services. The government's medical indemnity legislation package—specifically, the offer to extend the existing guarantee to United Medical Protection and Australasian Medical Insurance Ltd to 31 December 2003—is the safety net rural communities must have to ensure the protection of specialist services.
There are any number of Australians who, unfortunately, have brought about the need for legislation—whether it be in relation to public liability in general or medical indemnity—and who have expectations that can never be met. It may be that they do not know the onus of responsibility they have to themselves or that they are expecting more of any practitioner than he or she can possibly give. I never cease to be amazed when I hear some of the claims that are made on not just the medical profession but people through insurance claims in general. As a nation, we have to have some measure of responsibility and we have to have some limit on what we can expect from a doctor, a surgeon or anybody in any walk of life that has a responsibility to others. When I hear about doctors being sued up to 23 years after an action may have been taken, like most Australians I shake my head and wonder where we are getting to.
The legislation we are debating is absolutely necessary, and I commend the government for having the leadership to bring together all the Australian governments, as I said, whether it be on public liability or, in this case, on medical indemnity. I must congratulate the government on doing this, presenting what is very necessary. However, unless Australia as a whole starts to take a grip on where we are heading, we are never going to entirely settle the problem. There is a limit to what you can expect in performance from anyone, and doctors are probably in the gun there more than anybody. If somebody does not show incompetence, if somebody does not show that they are under the influence of some outside trigger but has done their level best, I wonder how people can sue them for having done what is obviously their level best. People go through the training and they are obviously judged by their peers to be competent. Without any doubt, many people simply want a perfect child; we all do. But, if we do not get one, we have to stop short of looking for an excuse to sue somebody to try to rectify something that can never be rectified.
When UMP was put in the hands of the administrator, the government stepped in to ensure that all Australians, particularly those in country areas, had continued access to specialist services and GP proceduralists. We picked up the tab from 29 April and will continue to do that to ensure, as I said, that people like paediatricians, obstetricians and neurosurgeons—not that there are any in my electorate; we have to travel to Western Sydney to access one—are there to be used by our people. I cannot emphasise enough just how crucial these services are to the electorate of Parkes. Government intervention has ensured that the much-needed services I mentioned and the specialist GP services can continue. For people in outlying communities such as Broken Hill, accessibility is crucial. Look at paediatrics. Without that service, people in Broken Hill would have to travel 300 kilometres to Mildura or 500 or 600 kilometres to Adelaide. The fact is that the smaller communities could not support these professionals—especially obstetricians—and we would have to travel to capital cities. In towns like Parkes, Dubbo and Broken Hill, we do have, I am happy to say, those who specialise in obstetrics and paediatrics and specialised GPs. We are tonight, I hope, passing bills to make it possible for all Australians, especially country Australians, to continue to enjoy the level of security we have had in the past. 
This government has probably done more to improve medical services in country areas in the last six years than has been done in the last 20. The amount of money—some $700 million—that has been put into trying to retain doctors, let alone specialist doctors, in rural areas has been quite outstanding. The intake of country students into medical schools around Australia has gone up from around eight per cent to around 25 per cent in a very short period of time, but that will not avail us much if the specialists within that fraternity are not available to look after our people on the spot. I commend the bills before us tonight. I commend the minister and the government for taking the action to bring together all the states and governments in Australia to deal with it. The great pity is, whether it be on medical indemnity or general public liability, we cannot be as responsible on this issue as we are on many others.

name: Kelly, De-Anne, MP
text:
—I rise to speak on the Medical Indemnity Bill 2002 bill and cognate bills tonight. They include a proposal from the minister to fund the incurred but not reported liabilities of medical defence organisations in situations where they do not have the adequate reserves to cover these liabilities, with a levy on members to fund the scheme. They also include a high-cost claims scheme to enable the Commonwealth to fund 50 per cent of the costs of pay-outs by medical indemnity insurers for sums greater than $2 million up to the limit of a practitioner's indemnity cover, as well as direct premium subsidies for doctors with especially high medical indemnity premiums. That scheme covers obstetricians and the like.
While these bills will certainly go a long way towards capping rising medical indemnity insurance premiums for doctors, they need to be backed by the states with significant tort and legal system reforms. As well, this bill provides for an incurred but not reported indemnity, IBNR, scheme. The reality is that some MDOs just do not have adequate funds to meet these claims for which they are liable but which have not yet been reported. These MDOs have not been charging high enough premiums. The government scheme, through this legislation, will ensure that MDOs with unfunded IBNRs are able to fund these liabilities over time through an affordable levy.
I would like to refer to some issues raised by the member for Lilley in his address to the House. He touched on the level of bulk-billing in Australia. The member for Lilley was very fulsome in his criticism of the government, as he always is. In an article in the Australian Financial Review of 27 November, the shadow minister for health and ageing, Mr Smith, said:
... the additional amount picked up by Australians and their families for increases in GP copayments alone is $331 million ...'
This requires some in-depth examination. I am grateful to the member for Boothby, who has done a great deal of research on levels of bulk-billing. He found that in 1990-91, the level of bulk-billing for vocationally registered GPs was 70.1 per cent . In September 2002, the figure was 70.4 per cent—virtually the same. The cries that the level of bulk-billing has declined are simply fatuous. The figures are the same now as they were 11 and 12 years ago. In fact, in 1984-85, the percentage of bulk-billing for total services was 43.2 per cent. I thank the member for Boothby for his excellent research in this area. 
What was the response of the government of the day in 1990-91 to the low level—70.1 per cent—of bulk-billing? The response proposed by the then minister, the Hon. Brian Howe, to these low levels of bulk-billing was to reduce the Medicare rebate. By the way, he did not see the figure of 70.1 per cent as being low; he actually saw it as very high, dangerously high. He reduced the Medicare rebate in November 1991 by $3.50 and subsequently, in November 1992, by $1.50. This was a copayment proposal which was later withdrawn. But the government of the day and the then minister for health found that the bulk-billing rate, which was the same as it is today, was too high. Isn't it amazing how the Labor Party changes their tune?
It is very interesting to look back through time—although not back to the 18th century, as the member for Blaxland did. He spoke about market forces being untrammelled in regard to the situation with medical indemnity and said that you cannot give everything to the market. Looking back in time, in answer to a question from Mr Melham about decreasing the Medicare rebate, Mr Howe said:
I am aware of reports which say that this change will discourage bulk billing and encourage doctors to lift their fees. I must stress that the government does not control or determine doctors' charges or whether they bulk bill or raise an account to the patient. These things are determined by the competitive forces or the marketplace.
He went on to say:
The national health strategy background paper No. 5 on the effect of co-payments on medical care clearly demonstrates that the major reason why doctors bulk bill is the competitive pressure on them to do so. Doctors who bulk bill do so now because they know it is attractive to patients and they wish to maintain a viable practice.
Despite the copayments that were being introduced, he further went on to say:
... I am confident that Medicare will continue to operate to ensure very high rates of bulkbilling.
Mind you, he saw 70.1 per cent as being a very high rate of bulk-billing. I do wish the member for Lilley would check Labor's history; and I am grateful to the member for Boothby for supplying those figures. According to the Labor Party and the then minister for health, we now have in Australia a very high rate of bulk-billing. In fact, were Mr Howe here now, he would no doubt still be trying to reduce the Medicare rebate through a copayment. Perhaps we should take a leaf out of Mr Howe's book when he was Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services in the Labor government.
I will comment on other suggestions for dealing with the so-called low level of bulk-billing—which, as we are now aware, the Labor Party in 1991 saw as a very high level of bulk-billing. It is interesting to look back and see how former Minister Howe was viewed then. I refer to the valedictory that Mr Keating, the then Prime Minister, gave for Mr Howe. He said:
... Brian enjoyed more substantial power than probably anybody in the Left of the Labor Party, or in the Left in Australia, since the war. While we have seen other luminaries on the stage, few have been as effective.
`Hear, hear' to that. The minister for health saw 70.1 per cent of bulk-billing as being a very high level—in fact, this luminary of the Left saw it as being so high that he decided it was necessary to reduce the rebate. We certainly should not ignore the advice from luminaries on the Left with regard to bulk-billing and Medicare rebates.
What theories now abound to address this level of bulk-billing?
