An article in the Age on 12 November suggested that country doctors have larger Medicare payments than their city colleagues and that country and city practices be offered bonus payments for agreeing to bulk-bill patients. Remember that this is for a level of bulk-billing that, according to the Labor Party in 1990-91 and one of their luminaries, was very high. As a rural and regional MP, let me explain what would happen were rural doctors to receive a higher level of rebate.
I make the point that rural doctors work very hard. The doctors in my electorate, there is no doubt, are exhausted. A practice has just closed. The two very good doctors in that practice advertised Australia-wide but could not attract a partner or a locum, and so they closed their practice. The reality is that the exhausted rural doctors will not find their colleagues in metropolitan areas saying, `Oh, we've got an additional Medicare rebate. What we'll do is tell our wives'—or husbands, as the case may be—`to leave their job and their friends in the city; we'll sell the house, we'll take the kids out of school and we'll relocate to Proserpine, Ayr, the Pioneer Valley, Sarina or the Mallee.' That is not going to happen. When you think about it, do you really imagine that people, including those in rural doctors associations—whom I have the greatest regard for—will uproot their family, leave their friends, sell their house and move to a country town because they will receive more money from the taxpayer? No, they will not. 
Putting aside the merits of giving country doctors a higher income, the reality is that it will not solve the problem of maldistribution of doctor numbers in my electorate and in most rural and regional electorates. We just do not have enough doctors in rural and regional Australia. I agree with the member for Blaxland when he says that reality is knocking at the door. He is quite right—reality is knocking at the door. It is probably the only thing that he said that I agree with, but he was right. We have a maldistribution of doctors. We do not need the cute suggestions coming from many doctor groups that we increase the Medicare rebate for rural doctors; although there may be other sound arguments for doing that, it will not increase the number of rural doctors. I suggest that we need geographically-allocated Medicare provider numbers; it should lie with the divisions of general practice in various areas. The truth is that doctors will not move from the cities to rural and regional—
—That'll be good. I'm for that.
—I'm amazed; the Labor Party agrees with something.
—Yes, I'm for that. I'm sure the government won't be, though.
—No other measure will encourage doctors to come and serve in rural and regional areas. I have heard the argument that it is civil conscription, but nobody is forcing a doctor to move to any area of Australia. They should not be forced. But, if the Medicare provider number is there with the division of general practice, you either take it up or you do not. If you want to live by the taxpayers' dollar, you need to serve where the need exists. As a rural and regional member, I have to say that quite often there is a lot of criticism that some of our constituents are subsidised. I disagree with that.
But let me tell you of one group that undoubtedly is subsidised, and that is doctors. A proportion of their income is given via the largesse of the taxpayer. The truth is that, in many areas, those very same taxpayers who contribute to supporting Medicare arrangements through their Medicare levy and all their other taxes and charges—because, as we know, the Medicare levy goes nowhere near paying for medical costs in Australia—do not have access to doctors at the same rate as their metropolitan cousins, and they are justified in asking why that situation should continue.
I will close on that note. I support wholeheartedly the legislation tonight. But I disagree with the member for Lilley—as does Mr Howe, the previous minister for health. We do not have a low level of bulk-billing; we have a very high level of bulk-billing, and well may it last. We do need to address very quickly the maldistribution of doctors, particularly for rural and regional areas. I commend the bill to the House.

name: Crosio, Janice, MP
text:
—I too rise in support of the Medical Indemnity Bill 2002 and associated legislation mainly to put to rest a number of points on what these bills are really about. We on this side of the House, while supporting the legislation, are very, very concerned that the government as a whole has not examined fully what the indemnity of doctors is about. When we look at the whole package of legislation that is the subject of this cognate debate, what we as government and opposition have to make sure of is that we have ongoing and viable medical indemnity insurance.
The package of legislation we are debating here tonight is a very short-term measure. If what we want is future reliability of insurance for doctors, these bills do not cover all the points. We are certainly concerned to make sure that one of the objectives of the legislation is to bring down the cost of medical indemnity insurance premiums, but the doctors at large are talking about where they are going to go in the future in being covered by insurance levies. 
In listening to the debate tonight, I was particularly interested in what the member for Dawson said. The member for Dawson gave the impression that people's problems with the availability of doctors are only in rural areas. I can advise the member for Dawson and any other National Party members—and the Liberal Party as well—that, if you come to areas of Western Sydney, you will find that at times the shortage of doctors is far greater as a percentage of population than many rural members have probably been experiencing in the past. I do not believe that this very short-term measure will overcome that.
We are looking at the medical indemnity insurance scheme that was announced by the government on 23 October 2002. It is certainly looking at a subsidy; it is certainly looking at providing a backup of guarantee to many doctors in the community at large and giving them assurances that they can continue to carry on their professions. But we have to do a little more than that. We have to be able to do more than just say to them, `We're going to give you that indemnity.' We are going to have to say that we are going to provide for the future without injuring patients who may be thinking in times to come of suing their doctors or suing doctors who may be incompetent. As legislators, we need to be able to provide a package that gives the community at large a level playing field where we know where we will be going in the future. Our medical profession may say that they are highly skilled, highly trained professionals and they know what they are doing. I say to them, `You are only human. You do occasionally make mistakes.' We do not always hear about them, but still they do happen.
When we are talking about packages of bills like the one before the House tonight, we have to look at the availability of provisions for organisations that are using state government funds, federal government funds and their own funds and who are at least servicing the community. They have got to have a guarantee—I know that—but so has the community.
Turning to the other bills in this cognate debate, I think of things like cost recovery. Where do we go from there? What are the major problems we may have with the package? Has there been enough consultation? Is the package itself a significant step forward? Are the goals that we are trying to achieve related to what the objectives are with the medical profession at large? Have we taken on board enough community concerns? Have we been able to evaluate some of the problems that have been experienced in the past but have now come forward as major problems?
If we look at some of the claims that have been made both at the community level and at the medical professional level, we wonder whether those claims have gone far enough. Are they substantial in terms of what they are trying to achieve? When we look at the regimes that we are trying to implement as parliamentarians and legislators, have we gone far enough? Are we looking at what the minister is trying to achieve with the factors determining what we are classifying as non-participating MDOs? Do they have sufficient funds to pay their non-reported liabilities? There are many still unanswered questions.
I know we on this side of the House keep saying that we are going to agree with the bills. We will probably move a minor amendment, and in the Senate we will probably go more definitively into the bills. But we have to give a lot of consideration to where we are going in the future and to future legislation before the House.
As I said, we certainly will support the bills. But in that support of the bills we have to be sure that we are not going to have a recurrent problem in the future. As I have said, personally I do not believe that these bills have gone far enough. I know that the Commonwealth is looking at perhaps paying a percentage of doctors' claims. We are looking at a payment that could be made by the Commonwealth to the MDOs or to the insurers being determined by a multiplying factor. I would like to have more answers as to what that multiplying factor is. I know that there are a number of exceptions, and that will be made clear in the future. In my area of Western Sydney, we have some very competent doctors; we also have some doctors who are very wary. For example, some doctors are very wary of going into obstetrics. They are saying to us, `We're going to move out of that profession because we don't believe that we're going to be covered with enough insurance indemnity to avoid facing future charges.' 
We as human beings have greater expectations than we had 20 or 30 years ago. In those days, when we went into hospital and put our life into the hands of a doctor, we believed that everything they were doing was right and above board. Today we seem to question a lot more of the decisions that they are making. As a profession, doctors are also concerned about that questioning—whether their professional capabilities are being questioned by the patient. Let me say this to the medical profession: that probably is not the case; what is being considered by the patient is the right to know. 
That is what I am really saying about these bills before the House. The important thing is the right to know. Are we certain of what we are doing and what we are trying to cover? Are we certain that every step that we are taking here now is going to be covered? Are we really certain that the medical profession will be happy with this? If they are not, they are going to be coming back to us—this year, next month, next year—and saying, `Well, it's not enough; we are still going to abandon obstetrics' or `We're not going to go into orthopaedics' or `We've decided that we're not going to operate any more.'
We do not need that. We need to have bills that will have the answers to some of the problems that the community at large has been experiencing. We need to have the bills debated before the House when we know that both sides of the House are in total agreement—when we feel that every `i' has been dotted and every `t' has been crossed. I am not certain that that has happened in the cognate debate that we have before the House tonight. After talking to members of the medical profession, I am also not certain whether they feel absolutely confident of what these bills will do. I know the legislative reforms are designed to ease the pressure that has been placed on the providers of medical indemnity. I say to them, `What are the pressures? Are there more ways to overcome them?'

name: Mossfield, Frank, MP
text:
—The Maturity Matters conference which was held in Perth at the end of October focused on a number of issues relating to our ageing population. They included economic and social issues brought about through Australia's declining birthrate, improved health services resulting in people living longer and employment insecurity resulting in many working people being placed prematurely in the early retirement category. We are told that, on present trends, this will result in the current job scarcity transforming into an employee and skill shortage by 2020. In the meantime, Australia has the twofold problem of older workers losing their jobs and an increasing cost of providing financial support for older Australians. There is also a problem for older Australians who have provided for their retirement in the form of superannuation, because their entitlements are being affected by the drought, overseas political issues and general fluctuations of the Australian and overseas financial markets.
The general view is that, in order to provide for an increasing ageing population, the government needs to provide for increased spending on retirement incomes or increased contributions to superannuation funds, review health services for older Australians and provide for an increased involvement of mature-age workers in the production of goods and services. To overcome these problems, a number of dangerous suggestions are being put forward. In the Sunday Telegraph last week, there is an article which states: 
The qualifying age for a pension will be raised to 70 under a Finance Department submission to reduce the financial burden of Australia's ageing population.
Earlier in the year, Senator Coonan actually raised the possibility of doing away with the age pension altogether. These are dangerous suggestions that would certainly be opposed by the Australian Labor Party.
On the issue of recruiting older people, the New South Wales Police Force is setting an example: people older than the normal recruiting age are now being accepted into the police force. But private employers do not appear to be recognising the value of older workers, if you take the view of the Qantas chief information officer, Fiona Balfour. She is quoted in an article in the Australian on Tuesday, 12 November, where she refers to the possible lay-off of IT staff. She states:
This is a remarkably middle-aged group—we are struggling to find enough space to recruit graduates, who we can recruit for tuppence.
Further in the article, Ms Balfour refers to a suggestion that Qantas may consider outsourcing its IT work to India. She says:
My preference is to have the work done in Australia. The whole point is, if you want support for these older systems in the future, these skills will not be available in Australia. In five to 10 years we might have to.
That is, they might have to outsource work to India. This raises two issues that I have spoken about in the past: firstly, the need for lifelong learning for Australian workers—which was another major theme of the Maturity Matters conference—to ensure that people's skills do not become redundant; and, secondly, the need to retain our manufacturing industry so that our skill base remains in Australia. To return to our friendly Qantas executive, Ms Balfour is further quoted as saying:
What is the average age of this group—
That reminds me of a report tabled in this parliament in June 2000 by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Workplace Relations titled Age counts. I will quote from one submission from this report. It states:
Drake's research shows that negative attitudes about older workers was widespread. About 70 per cent of Australian firms said that they would retrench executives over 50 ahead of others because they saw them as inflexible and unwilling to change. Negative attitudes about older executives refusing to reskill, however, are not proven since `86 per cent of senior workers are more than happy to take up training opportunities when offered to them.' 
Clearly there is a need for a change of attitude by private employers relating to the employment of older workers. A positive spin on employing older workers was put to the standing committee by Professor Encel, who explained:
... if you train a 25-year-old in cutting edge technology, what you actually do is make him or her more mobile. So the guarantee that they will stay with the firm that trained them is very thin ...
There is no doubt that Australians are living longer, which raises many opportunities and challenges for our policy makers. Indeed, the survival of our high standard of living will depend on us harnessing the skills and commitment of our maturing population.
